note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

div.head: Scena prima:
div.stage: Enter the Duke of Orleans, and the Earle of Amiens at ſeverall doores.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.p: _MOrrow my Lord of Orleance.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: You ſalute me like a ſtranger; brother Orleance were to me a Title more belonging, whom you call the husband of your ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Would the circumſtances of your brotherhood had never offer'd cauſe to make our converſation leſſe familiar: I meet you like a hinde|rance in your way: your great law ſuit is now upon the tongue, and ready for a judgement.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Came you from the Hall now?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Without ſtay; the Court is full, and ſuch a preſſe of people does attend the iſſue, as if ſome great man were brought to his araignment.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Every mothers ſonne of all that multitude of hearers went to be a witneſſe of the miſery your ſiſters fortunes muſt have come to, if my adverſary who did love her firſt, had been her husband.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: The ſucceſſe may draw a teſtimony from them to confirme the ſame opinion, but they went prepar'd with no ſuch hope or purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: And did you intreat, the number of them that are come with no ſuch hope or purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Tuſh, your own experience of my heart can an|ſwer ye.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: This doubtfull, makes me clearly underſtand your diſpoſition.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: If your cauſe be juſt,
I wiſh you a concluſion like your cauſe.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: I can have any common charity to ſuch a prayer
From a friend I would expect a love to proſper in;
Without exceptions ſuch a love as might
Make all my under takings thankfull to't;
Preciſely juſt is ſeldome faithfull in our wiſhes
To another mans deſires: Farewell. Exit Orl.

div.stage: Enter Montague having a Purſe, Duboys, Longueville, and Voramer the Page with two Gaskets.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Here comes your adverſaries brother in law.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: The Lord of Amiens.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: From the Hall I thinke.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: I did ſo: ſave your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: That's a wiſh my Lord, as courteous to my preſent ſtate,
As ever honeſt mind was thankfull for;
For now my ſafety muſt expoſe it ſelfe
To queſtion: yet to look for any free
Or hearty ſalutation (ſir from you)
Would be unreaſonable in me.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Your ſiſter is my adverſaries wife;
That neerneſſe needs muſt conſequently draw
Your inclination to him.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: I will grant
Him all the neerneſſe his alliance claimes,
And yet be nothing leſſe impartiall
My Lord of Montague.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Lord of Montague yet:
But (ſir) how long the dignity or ſtate
Belonging to it will continue, ſtands
Upon the dangerous paſſage of this houre,
Either for ever more to be confirm'd,
Or like the time wherein twas pleaded, gone:
Gone with it, never to be call'd again.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Juſtice direct your proceſſe to the end;
To both your perſons my reſpect ſhall ſtil
Be equall; but the righteous cauſe is that
Which bears my wiſhes to the ſide it holds,
Where, ●ver may it proſper. Exit Amiens.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Then my thanks
Are proper to you, if a man may raiſe
A confidence upon a lawfull ground
I have no reaſon to be once perplexed
With any doubtfull motion, Longueville,
That Lord of Amiens, (didſt obſerve him?) has
A worthy nature in him.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Either tis his nature or his cunning.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: That's the vizard of moſt mens actions,
Whoſe diſſembled lives
Do carry onely the ſimilitude
Of goodneſſe on 'em, but for him
Honeſt behaviour makes a true report,
What diſpoſition does inhabit him,
Eſſentiall vertue.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Then tis pitty that
Injurious Orleance is his brother.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: He is but his brother in law.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Law? that's as bad.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: How is your Law as bad? I rather wiſh
The hangman thy executor then that
Equivocation ſhould be ominous.

div.stage: Enter two Lawyers, and two Credit●rs.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Some of your Lawyers.—

sp.speaker: 1 Law.
sp.l: What is ominous?

sp.speaker: 2 Law.
sp.l: Let no diſtruſt trouble your Lordſhips thought.

sp.speaker: 1 Law.
sp.l: The evidences of your queſtion'd land
Ha' not much as any literall
Advantage in 'em to be made againſt
Your title.

sp.speaker: 2 Law.
sp.l: And your Councell underſtands
The buſineſſe fully.

sp.speaker: 1 Law.
sp.l: Th'are induſtrious, juſt.

sp.speaker: 2 Law.
sp.l: And very confident.

sp.speaker: 1 Law.
sp.l: Your ſtate endures
A voluntary tryall; like a man
Whoſe honours are maliciouſly accus'd.

sp.speaker: 2 Law.
sp.l: The Accuſation ſerves to cleare his cauſe.

sp.speaker: 1 Law.
sp.l: And to approve his truth more.

sp.speaker: 2 Law.
sp.l: So ſhall all
Your adverſaries pleadings ſtrengthen your
Poſſeſſion.

sp.speaker: 1 Law.
sp.l: And be ſet upon record
To witneſſe the hereditary right
Of you and yours.

sp.speaker: 2 Law.
sp.l: Courage, you have the law.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: And you the profits.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: If diſcouragement
Could worke upon me, your aſſurances
Would put me ſtrongly into heart again;
But I was never fearfull: and let fate
Deceive my expectation, yet I am
Prepared againſt dejection.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.l: So are we.

sp.speaker: 2 Cred.
sp.l: We have received a comfortable hope
That all will ſpeed well.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: What is he Duboys?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: A Creditor.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I thought ſo, for he ſpeaks
As if he were a partner in his ſtate.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Sir, I am largely indebted to your loves.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: More to their purſes.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Which you ſhall not loſe.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.l: Your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: That's another creditor.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.l: Has intereſt in me.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: You have more of him.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.l: And I have had ſo many promiſes
From theſe and all your learned Councellors,
How certainly your cauſe wil proſper: that—

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: You brought no Serjeants with you?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: To attend his ill ſucceſſe.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Good ſir, I will not be
Unthankfull either to their induſtries
Or your affections.

sp.speaker: 1 Law.
sp.l: All your land (my Lord)
Is at the bar now, give me but ten Crowns
Ile ſave you harmleſſe.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Take him at his word;
If he does loſe, you're ſav'd by miracle,
For I never knew a lawyer yet undone.

sp.speaker: 1 Law.
sp.l: Then now you ſhall ſir, if this proſpers not.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Sir, I beſeech you doe not force your voyce
To ſuch a loudneſſe, but be thrifty now;
Preſerve it till you come to plead at bar
It wil be much more profitable in
The ſatisfaction then the promiſe.

sp.speaker: 1 Law.
sp.l: Is not this a ſatisfaction to engage
My ſelfe for this aſſurance, if he—

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: No ſir, my ruine never ſhall import
Anothers loſſe, if not by accident,
And that my purpoſe is not guilty of:
You are engaged in nothing but your care. Exit Law.
Attend the Procurator to the Court,
Obſerve how things incline, and bring me word.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I dare not ſir; if I be taken there,
Mine eares will be in danger.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Why? haſt thou
Committed ſomething that deſerves thine eares?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: No, but I feare the noyſe; my hearing will be
Periſhed by the noiſe; tis as good 't want
A member, as to looſe the uſe —

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: The ornament is excepted.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Well my Lord
Ile put 'em to the hazzard. Exit Long.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.l: Your deſires be proſperous to you.

sp.speaker: 2 Cred.
sp.l: Our beſt prayers waite
Upon your fortune. Exeunt Cred.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: For your ſelves, not him.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Thou canſt not blame 'em: I am in their debts.

sp.speaker: Ʋer.
sp.l: But had your large expence (a part whereof
You owe 'em) for unprofitable Silkes
And Laces, been beſtowed among the poore,
That would have prayd the right way for you:
Not upon you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: For unprofitable Silkes
And Laces? now believe me honeſt boy
Th'aſt hit upon a reprehenſion that belongs
Unto me.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: By—my Lord,
I had not ſo unmannerly a thought,
To reprehend you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Why I love thee for't.
Mine own acknowledgement confirmes thy words:
For once I do remember, comming from
The Mercers, where my Purſe had ſpent it ſelfe
On thoſe unprofitable toyes thou ſpeakſt of,
A man halfe naked with his poverty
Did meet me, and requeſted my reliefe:
I wanted whence to give it, yet his eyes
Spoke for him, thoſe I could have ſatisfied
With ſome unfruitfull ſorrow, (if my teares
Would not have added rather to his griefe,
Then eaſ'd it) but the true compaſſion that
I ſhould have given I had not: this began
To make me think how many ſuch mens wants
The vaine ſuperfluous coſt I wore upon
My outſide would have clothed, and left my ſelfe
A habit as becomming: to encreaſe
This new conſideration there came one
Clad in a garment plaine and thrifty, yet
As decent as theſe faire deare follies; made
As if it were of purpoſe to deſpiſe
The vanity of ſhow: his purſe had ſtill
The power to doe a charitable deed,
And did it.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Yet your inclination, ſir,
Deſervd no leſſe to be commended, then his action.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Prethee do not flatter me;
He that intends well, yet deprives himſelfe
Of means to put his good thoughts into deed,
Deceives his purpoſe of the due reward
That goodneſſe merits: O antiquity
Thy great examples of Nobility
Are out of imitation, or at leaſt
So lamely follow'd, that thou art as much
Before this age in vertue, as in time.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Sir, it muſt needs be lamely followed, when
The chiefeſt men love to follow it
Are for the moſt part cripples.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Who are they?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Souldiers, my Lord, ſouldiers.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Tis true Duboys: but if the Law diſables me no more
For Noble actions, then good purpoſes,
Ile practice how to exerciſe the worth
Commended to us by our anceſtors;
The poore neglected ſouldier ſhall command
Me from a Ladies Courtſhip, and the forme
Ile ſtudy ſhall no more be taught me by
The Taylor, but the Scholler; that expence
Which hitherro has been to entertaine
Th' intemperate pride and pleaſure of the taſte
Shall fill my Table more to ſatisfie,
And leſſe to ſurfeit.
What an honeſt worke it would be; when we finde
A Virgin in her poverty, and youth
Inclining to be tempted, to imploy
As much perſwaſion, and as much expence
To keep her upright as men uſe to do upon her falling.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Tis charity that many mayds wil be unthankful for,
And ſome will rather take it for a wrong,
To buy 'em out of their inheritance,
The thing that they were born to.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Longueville thou bringſt a cheerfull promiſe in thy face.
There ſtands no pale report upon thy cheeke,
To give me feare or knowledge of my loſſe, tis red and lively.
How proceeds my ſuit?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: That's with labour ſir, a labour that to thoſe of Hercules
May adde another; or (at leaſt) be cald
A imitation of this burning ſhirt:
For twas a paine of that unmercifull
Perplexity, to ſhoulder through the throng
Of people that attended your ſucceſſe:
My ſweaty linnen fixt upon my skin,
Still as they puld me, tooke that with it; 'twas
A feare I ſhould have left my fleſh among 'em:
Yet I was patient, for (me thought) the toyle
Might be an emblem of the difficult
And weary paſſage to get out of Law.
And to make up the deare ſimilitude,
When I was forth ſeeking my handkircher
To wipe my ſweat off, I did finde a cauſe
To make me ſweat more, for my Purſe was loſt
Among their finger.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: There twas rather found.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: By them.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: I mean ſo.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Well, I will reſtore
Thy dammage to thee: how proceeds my ſuit?

sp.speaker: Lang.
sp.l: Like one at Brokers; I thinke forfeited.
Your promiſing councell at the firſt
Put ſtrongly forward with a labour'd ſpeed,
And ſuch a violence of pleading, that
His fee in Sugar-candie ſcarce will make
His throat a ſatisfaction for the hurt
He did it, and he carried the whole cauſe
Before him with ſo cleare a paſſage, that
The people in the favour of your ſide
Cried Montague, Montague: in the ſpight of him
That cryed out ſilence, and began to laugh
Your adverſaries Advocate to ſcorn:
Who like a cunning foot-man? ſet me forth
With ſuch a temperate eaſie kind of courſe
To put him into exerciſe of ſtrength,
And follow'd his advantages ſo cloſe,
That when your hot mouthed pleader thought 'had wonne,
Before he reacht it, he was out of breath,
And then the other ſtript him.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: So all is loſt.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: But how I know not; for (me thought) I ſtood
Confounded with the clamour of the Court,
Like one embarqued upon a ſtorm at Sea,
Where the tempeſtuous noiſe of Thunder mixt
With roaring of the billows, and the thick
Imperfect language of the Sea-men, takes
His underſtanding and his ſafety both
Together from him.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Thou doſt bring ill news

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Of what I was unwilling to have been
The firſt reporter.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Didſt obſerve no more?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: At leaſt no better.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Then th' art not inform'd
So well as I am; I can tell thee that
Will pleaſe thee, for when all elſe left my cauſe,
My very adverſaries tooke my part.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: —whoſoever told you that abuſed you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Credit me, he took my part
When all forſook me.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Took it from you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Yes I meane ſo, and I think he had juſt cauſe
To take it when the verdict gave it him.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: His Spirit would ha' ſunke him, ere he could
Have carried an ill fortune of this waight ſo lightly.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Nothing is a miſery unleſſe our weakneſſe apprehend it ſo;
We cannot be more faithfull to our ſelves
In any thing that's manly, then to make
Ill fortune as contemptible to us
As it makes us to others.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Here come they
Whoſe very countenances will tell you how
Contemptible it is to others.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: The ſir of Knighthood may be given him, ere
They heare you now.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Good ſir but a word.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: How ſoon the loſſe of wealth makes any man
Grow out of knowledge.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Let me ſee I pray ſir,
Never ſtood you upon the pillory?

sp.speaker: 1 Law.
sp.l: The Pillory?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: O now I know you did not.
Y'ave eares, I thought ye had loſt 'em; pray obſerve,
Here's one that once was gracious in our eyes.

sp.speaker: 1 Law.
sp.l: O my Lord, have an eye upon him.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: But ha' you nere a Counſell to redeeme
His Land yet from the judgement?

sp.speaker: 2 Law.
sp.l: None but this, a writ of errour to remove the cauſe.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: No more of errour, we have been in that too much already.

sp.speaker: 2 Law.
sp.p: If you will reverſe the judgement, you muſt truſt to that delay.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Delay? Indeed he's like to truſt to that,
With you has any dealing.

sp.speaker: 2 Law.
sp.p: Ere the Law proceeds to an habere facias poſ|ſeſſionem.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: That's a language ſir, I underſtand not.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Th'art a very ſtrange unthankfull fellow to have taken Fees of ſuch a liberall meaſure, and then give a man hard words for's money.

sp.speaker: 1 Law.
sp.l: If men will hazzard their ſalvations,
What ſhould I ſay? I've other buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Y'are ith' right;
That's it you ſhould ſay now proſperity has left me.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.l: Have an eye upon him; if
We loſe him now, he's gone for ever; ſtay
And dog him: Ile goe fetch the officers.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Dog him you blood-hound: by this point thou ſhalt more ſafely dog an angry Lion then attempt him.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Doe but ſteere to fetch a Serjeant; and (beſides your loſſe
Of labour) Ile have you beaten, till
Thoſe caſements in your faces be falſe lights.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Falſer then thoſe you ſell by.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Who gave you Commiſſion to abuſe my friends thus?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Sir, are thoſe your friends that would betray you?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Tis to ſave themſelves rather then betray me.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.l: Your Lordſhip makes a juſt conſtruction of it.

sp.speaker: 2 Cred.
sp.l: All our deſire is but to get our own.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Your wives deſires and yours do differ then.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: So far as my ability will goe
You ſhall have ſatisfaction Longeville,

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: And leave your ſelfe neglected; every man
Is firſt a debtor to his own demands, being honeſt.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: As I take it ſir, I did
Not entertaine you for my counſellor.

sp.speaker: Ilong.
sp.l: Counſel's the office of a ſervant,
When the maſter fals upon a danger: as
Defence is never threaten with your eyes,
They are no cockatrices; do you heare?
Talke with a Girdler, or a Milner,
He can informe you of a kind of men
That firſt undid the profit of thoſe trades
By bringing up the forme of carrying
There morglachs in their hands: with ſome of thoſe
A man may make himſelfe a priviledge
To aske a queſtion at the priſon gates,
Without your good permiſſion.

sp.speaker: 2 Cred.
sp.l: By your leave.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Stay ſir, what one example ſince the time
That firſt you put your hat off to me, have
You noted in me to encourage you
To this preſumption? by the juſtice now
Of thine own rule, I ſhould begin with thee,
I ſhould turn thee away ungratified
For all thy former kindneſſe, forget
Thou ever didſt me any ſervice: tis not feare
Of being arreſted makes me thus incline
To ſatisfie you; for you ſee by him,
I loſt not all defences with my ſtate;
The curſes of a man to whom I am
Beholding terrifie me more, then all
The violence he can purſue me with.
Duboys, I did prepare me for the worſt;
Theſe two ſmall Cabinets doe comprehend
The ſum of all the wealth that it hath pleaſed
Adverſity to leave me, one as rich
As th' other, both in Jewels; take thou this,
And as the Order put within it ſhall
Direct thee, diſtribute it half between
Thoſe Creditors, and th' other halfe among
My ſervants: for (ſir) they are my creditors
As well as you are, they have truſted me
With their advancement: if the value faile,
To pleaſe you all, my firſt increaſe of meanes
Shall offer you a fuller payment; be content
To leave me ſomething, and imagine that
You put a new beginner into credit.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.p: So proſper our own bleſſings, as we wiſh you to your merit.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Are your ſilences of diſcontent, or of ſorrow?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Sir, we would not leave you.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Do but ſuffer us to follow you, and what our preſent means, or induſtries hereafter can provide, ſhall ſerve you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: O deſire me not to live
To ſuch a baſeneſſe, as to be maintained
By thoſe that ſerve me; pray be gone, I wil
Defend your honeſties to any man
That ſhal report you have forſaken me;
I pray be gone. Exeunt Servants and Crediers.
Why doſt thou weep my boy,
Becauſe I doe not bid thee goe too?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: No, I weep (my Lord) becauſe I would not goe;
I feare you will command me.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: No my child,
I wil not; that would diſcommend th'intent
Of all my other actions: thou art yet
Unable to adviſe thy ſelfe a courſe,
Should I put thee to ſeeke it; after that
I muſt excuſe or at the leaſt forgive
Any uncharitable deed that can be done againſt my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Ʋer.
sp.l: Every day (my Lord) I tarry with you, Ile account
A day of bleſſing to me; for I ſhall
Have ſo much leſſe time left me of my life
When I am from you: and if miſery
Befall you (which I hope ſo good a man
Was never born to) I wil take my part,
And make my willingneſſe increaſe my ſtrength
To beare it. In the Winter I will ſpare
Mine own clothes from my ſelfe to cover you;
And in the Summer, carry ſome of yours
To eaſe you: Ile doe any thing I can.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Why, thou art able to make miſery
Aſhamed of hurting, when thy weakneſſe can
Both beare it, and deſpiſe it: Come my boy
I will provide ſome better way for thee
Then this thou ſpeakſt of; tis the comfort that
Ill fortune has undone me into the faſhion:
For now in this age moſt men do begin,
To keep but one boy, that kept many men. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Orleans, a Servant, his Ladie following.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Where is ſhe? call her.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I attend you ſir.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Your friend ſweet Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: What friend, good my Lord?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Your Montague, Madam, he will ſhortly want
Thoſe Courtly graces that you love him for;
The means wherewith he purchaſed this, and this,
And all his own proviſions to the leaſt
Proportion of his feeding or his clothes,
Came out of that inheritance of land
Which he unjuſtly lived on: but the law
Has given me right in't, and poſſeſſion; now
Thou ſhalt perceive his bravery vaniſh, as
This Jewell does from thee now, and theſe Pearles
To him that owes 'em.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ye are the owner ſir of every thing that does belong to me.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: No, not of him, ſweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: O good God!

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: But in a while your mind will change, and be
As ready to diſclaime him; when his wants
And miſeries have periſh'd his good face,
And taken off the ſweetneſſe that has made
Him pleaſing in a womans underſtanding.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O Heaven, how gratious had Creation been
To women, who are borne without defence,
If to our hearts there had been doores through which
Or husbands might have lookt into our thoughts,
And made themſelves undoubtfull.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Made 'em madde.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: With honeſt women.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Thou doſt ſtile pretend
A title to that vertue: prethee let
Thy honeſty ſpeak freelie to me now.
Thou knoweſt that Montaigue of whoſe Land
I am the maſter, did affect three firſt,
And ſhould have had thee, if the ſtrength of friends
Had not prevail'd above thine own conſent.
I have undone him; tell me how thou doeſt
Conſider his ill fortune and my good.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ile tell you juſtly his iundoing is
An argument for pitty? and for teares
In all their diſpoſitions that have known
The honour and the goodneſſe of his life:
Yet that addition of proſperity,
Which you have got by't, no indifferent man
Will malice or repine at, if the Law
Be not abuſed in 't; howſoever ſince
You have the upper fortune of him, 'twill
Be ſome diſhonour to you to beare your ſelfe
With any pride or glory over him.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: This may be truly ſpoken, but in thee
It is not honeſt.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Yes, ſo honeſt, that I care not if the chaſt Penelope
Were now alive to hear me.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Who comes there?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My brother.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Save yee.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Now ſir, you have heard of proſperous Montague.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: No ſir, I have heard of Montague,
But of your proſperity.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Is he diſtracted.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: He does beare his loſſe with ſuch a noble ſtrength
Of patience that,
Had fortune eyes to ſee him, ſhe would weepe
For having hurt him, and pretending that
Shee did it but for triall of his worth:
Hereafter ever love him.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: I perceive you love him, and becauſe (I muſt confeſſe)
He does deſerve that though for ſome reſpects,
I have not given him that acknowledgement,
Yet in mine honour I did ſtill conclude to uſe him nobly.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Sir, that will become your reputation and make me grow proud of your alliance.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: I did reſerve the doing of this friendſhip till I had
His fortunes at my mercy, that the world
May tell him 'tis a willing courteſie.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: This change wil make me happy.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Tis a change; thou ſhalt behold it, then obſerve me when
That Montague had poſſeſſion of my Land,
I was his rivall, and at laſt obtain'd
This Lady who by promiſe of her own
Affection to him, ſhould ha bin his wife;
I had her, and withheld her like a pawne,
Till now my Land is rendred to me againe,
And ſince it is ſo, you ſhall ſee I have
The conſcience not to keep her—give him her— draws
For by the faithfull temper of my ſword, ſhee ſhall not tarry with me.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Give me way — draws.
Thou moſt unworthy man—give me way
Or by the wrong he does the Innocent,
Ile end thy miſery and his wickedneſſe, together.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Stay and let me juſtifie
My husband in that, I have wrong'd his bed
sp.stage: Enter Amiens in amazement, the ſervants following him.
sp.l: Never—all ſhames that can afflict me fall
Upon me if I ever wrong'd you;

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Didſt thou not confeſſe it?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Twas to ſave your bloud from ſhedding, that has
Turn'd my brothers edge;
He that beholdes our thoughts as plainely as
Our faces, knowes it, I did never hurt
My honeſty but by accuſing it.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Womens conſents are ſonner credited
Then their denials: and Ile never truſt
Her body that prefers any defence
Before the ſafety of her honour—here— Enter ſervant
Show forth that ſtranger—give me not a word
Thou ſeeſt a danger readie to be tempted.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Caſt that upon me rather then my ſhame,
And as I am now dying I wil now—
That I am honeſt.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Put her out of dores; but that I feare my land
May go againe to Montague, I would kill thee, I am loth,
To make a beggar of him that way; or elſe—
Go now you have the liberty of fleſh,
And you may put it to a double uſe,
One for your pleaſure, th'other to maintaine
Your welbeloved, he wil want. Exit Lady
In ſuch a charitable exerciſe
The vertue wil excuſe you for the vice. Exit Orleans.

div.stage: Enter Amiens drawne, Montague, Vercamor meeting.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: What meanes your Lordſhip?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: For the love of God—

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Thou haſt advantage of mee, caſt away this buckler.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: So he is Sir, for he lives
With one that is undone—a voyd us boy.

sp.speaker: Ʋer.
sp.l: Ile firſt avoid my ſafety,
Your Rapier ſhall be button'd, with my heade before it touch my Maſter.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: You know my ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Yes ſir.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: For a whore?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: You lye, and ſhall lie lower if you dare abuſe her honor.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I am honeſt.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Honeſt!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Upon my faith I am.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: What did then perſwade thee to condemn thy ſelf?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Your ſafety.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I had rather be expoſ'd
To danger, then diſhonor; th'aſt betray'd
The reputation of my familie
More baſely by the falſeneſſe of that word,
Then that thou haſt delivered me aſleepe
Into the hands of baſe enemie.
Reliefe will never make thee ſenſible
Of thy diſgraces; let thy wants compell thee to it. Exit

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O I am a miſerable woman.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Why Madam? are you utterly without means to relieve you?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I have nothing ſir, unleſſe by changing of theſe cloaths for worſe, and then at laſt the worſt for na|kedneſſe.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Stand off boy, nakedneſſe would be a change
To pleaſe us Madam, to delight us both.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What nakedneſſe ſir?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Why the nakedneſſe of body Madam, we were Lovers once.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Never diſhoneſt Lovers.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Honeſtie has no allowance now to give our ſelves.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Nor you allowance againſt honeſtie.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Ile ſend my Boy hence, opportunitie
Shall be our ſervant, come and meet me firſt
With kiſſes like a ſtranger at the doore,
And then invite me neerer to receive
A mor● familiar inward welcome—where,
Inſtead of tapers made of Virgins wax
Th'increaſing flames of our deſires ſhall light
Us to a banquet: and before the taſte
Be dull with ſatisfaction, Ile prepare
A nouriſhment compos'd of every thing
That beares a naturall friendſhip to the bloud,
And that ſhall ſet another edge upon't,
Or elſe between the courſes of the feaſt
Wee'l dallie out an exerciſe of time,
That ever as one appetite expires another may ſucceede it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O my Lord, how has your nature loſt her worthineſſe?
When our affections had their liberty,
Or kiſſes met as temperatelie as
The hands of ſiſters, or of brothers, that
Our blouds were then as moving; then you were
So noble, that I durſt have truſted your
Embraces in an opportunity
Silent enough to ſerve a raviſher,
And yet come from you—undiſhonor'd—how
You think me altered, that you promiſe your
Attempt ſucceſſe I know not; but were all
The ſweet temptations that deceive us ſet
On this ſide, and one that ſide all the waiters,
Theſe neither ſhould perſwade me nor the force.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Then miſery may waſte your body.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Yes, but luſt ſhall never.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I have found you ſtill as uncorrupted as I left you firſt
Continue ſo; and I wil ſerve you with
As much devotion as my word, my hand
Or purſe can ſhow you; and to juſtifie
That promiſe, here is half the wealth I have,
Take it, you owe me nothing, till you fall
From vertue, which the better to protect
I have bethought me of a preſent meanes
Give me the Letter; this commends my Boy
Into the ſervice of a Lady, whoſe
Free goodneſſe you have bin acquainted with Lamira.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Sir I know her.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Then believe her entertainment wil be noble to you;
My boy ſhall bring you thither: and relate
Your manner of misfortune if your own
Report needs any witneſſe: ſo I kiſſe your hand good Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir, I know not how to promiſe, but I cannot be unthankfull.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: All that you can implore in thankfulneſſe
Be yours, to make you the more proſperous.
Farwell my boy,— I am not yet oppreſſ'd. Exit Lady Ʋera.
Having the power to helpe one that's diſtreſſ'd.

div.head: Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: What ſhall we do now: ſwords are out of uſe,
And words are out of credit.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: We muſt ſerve.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: The meanes to get a ſervice will firſt ſpend
Our purſes; and except we can allow
Our ſelves an entertainment, ſervice will
Neglect us; now tis grown into a doubt
Whether the Mr. or the ſervant gives the countenance.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Then fall in with Miſtreſſes.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: They keep more ſervants now (indeed) then men,
But yet the age is grown ſo populous
Of thoſe attendants, that the women are
Grown full to.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: What ſhall we propund our ſelves?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I'le think on't.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Do; Old occupations have too many ſetters up to proſper, ſome uncommon trade would thrive now.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Wee'l ee'n make up ſome half a dozen proper men,
And ſhould not we get more
Then all your female ſinners?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: If the houſe be ſeated as it ſhould be privately.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I but that would make a multitude of witches.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: VVitches? how prethee?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Thus the bands would all turn witches to revenge
Themſelves upon; us and the women that
Come to us, for diſguiſes muſt wear beards,
And that's they ſay, a token of a witch.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: VVhat ſhall we then do.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: VVe muſt ſtudy on't,
VVith more conſideration; ſtay Duboyes
Are not the Lord of Orleans and the Lord
Of Amiens enemies?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Yes, what of that.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Methinks the factions of two ſuch great men.
Should give a promiſe of advanc●ment now
To us that want it.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Let the plot be thine, and in the enterprize Ile ſe|cond thee.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I have it, wee will firſt ſet down our ſelves
The Method of a quarrell; and make choyce
Of ſome frequented Taverne; or ſuch a place
Of common notice to perform it in
By way of undertaking to maintaine
The ſeverall honours of thoſe enemies.
Thou for the Lord of Orleanes; I for Amiens.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: I like the project, and I think 'twill take
The better, ſince their difference firſt did riſe
From his occaſion whom we followed once.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: We cannot hope leſſe after the report,
Then entertainment or gratuity,
Yet thoſe are ends, I do not aime at moſt;
Greater ſpirits that are needy, and will thrive,
Muſt labour whiles ſuch troubles are alive. Exeunt

sp.speaker: La p.
sp.p: Slander is ſharper then the ſword. I have fed this three dayes upon leafe Tobacco, for want of other Victuals.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: You have liv'd the honeſter Captaine; but be not ſo dejected, but hold up thy head, and meate wil ſooner fall i'thy mouth.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: I care not ſo much for meat, ſo I had but good liquor, for which my guts croak like ſo many Frogs for raine.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: It ſeemes, you are troubled with the wind-Collick Captaine, ſwallow a bullet: tis preſent remedy i'le aſſure you.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: A bullet; if you be Captain, my panch is nothing but a pile of bullets; when I was in any ſervice I ſtood be|tween my Generall and the ſhot, like a mud-wall; I am all lead, from the crown of the head to the ſoale of the foot, not a ſound bone about me.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: It ſeems you have bin in terrible hot ſervice Captaine.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: It has ever bin the fate of the low Country wars to ſpoile many a man, I ha' not bin the firſt nor ſhall not be the laſt: but ile tell you ſir, (hunger has brought it in to minde) I ſerved once at the Siege of Braſte 'tis me|morable to this day, where we were in great diſtreſſe for victuals, whole troops fainted more for want of food then for blood, and died, yet we were reſolved to ſtand it out; I my ſelf was but then Gentleman of a Company, and had as much need as any man, and in|deed I had periſhed had not a miraculous providence pre|ſerved me.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: As how good Captaine?

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Marry ſir ee'n as I was fainting and falling down for want of ſuſtenance, the enemy made a ſhot at me, and ſtruck me full ith' paunch with a penny loaf.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Inſtead of a bullet!

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: In ſtead of a bullet.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: That was miraculous in deed; and that loaf ſuſtained you.

sp.speaker: Lap-p.
sp.p: Nouriſhed me or I had famiſhed with the reſt.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: You have done worthy acts being a ſouldier, and now you ſhall give me leave to requite your tale, and to acquaint you with the moſt notorious deeds that I have done being a Courtier. I proteſt Captain I wil lie no more then you have done.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: I can indure no lies.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: I know you cannat Captaine, therefore ile on|ly tell you of ſtrange things, I did once a deed of chari|ty for it ſelf; I aſſiſted a poor widdow in a ſute, and obtained it, yet I proteſt I took not a penny for my labour.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Tis no ſuch ſtrange thing.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: By Mars Captaine, but it is, and a very ſtrange thing too in a Courtier, it may take the upper hand of your penny loaf for a miracle. I could ha' told you how many Ladies have languiſhed for my love, and how I was once ſollicited by the mother, the daughter, and grand-mother out of the leaſt of which I might have digg'd my ſelfe a fortune; they were all great Ladies, for two of them were ſo big I could hardly em|brace them: but I was ſluggiſh in my riſing courſes, and therefore let them paſſe; what meanes I had is ſpent up|on ſuch as had the wit to cheat me; That wealth being gon, I have only bought experience with it, with a ſtrong hope to cheat others; but ſee here comes the much declin|ed Montague, who had all the Man or houſes, which were the body of his eſtate overthrowen by a great winde.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: How by a great winde? was he not over thrown by law?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Yes, marry was he: but there was terrible puffing and blowing before he was overthrown, if you obſerv'd, and believe it Captain, ther's no wind ſo dangerous to a building as a lawyers breath.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: What's he with him?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: An eminent Citizen. Mounſier Mallicorne, lets ſtand a ſide and liſten their deſign.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Sir, profit is the Crown of labour, it is the life, the ſoule of the induſtrious Merchant, in it he makes his pa|radiſe, and for it neglects Wife, Children, Friends, Pa|rents, nay all the world, and delivers up himſelfe to the violence of ſtormes, and to be tos'd into unknown ayres; as there is no faculty ſo perillous, ſo ther's none ſo worthy profitable.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Sir, I am very well poſſeſt of it, and what of my poore fortunes remaines, I would gladly hazzard upon the Sea; it cannot deale worſe with me then the Land, though it ſinck or throw it in the hands of Pirats. I have yet five hundred pounds left, and your honeſt and worthy acquaintance may make me a young Mer|chant; th'one moity of what I have I would gladly ad|venture.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: How adventure? you ſhall hazzard nothing: you ſhall only joyne with me in certaine commodities that are ſafe arrived unto the Key; you ſhall neither be in doubt of danger nor dammage; But ſo much mony disburſt, ſo much receive; ſir I would have you conceive I purſue it not for any good your money wil do me, but meerly out of mine own freeneſſe and courteſie to plea|ſure you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: I can believe no leſſe, and you expreſſe a noble nature, ſeeking to build up a man ſo ruin'd as my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Captaine here is ſubject for us to worke upon if we have wit; you hear that there is money yet left, and it is going to be layd out in Rattels, Bels, Hobby-Horſes, brown paper, or ſome ſuch like ſale commodities; now it would do better in our purſes, upon our backs in good Gold-lace, and Scarlet, and then we might pur|ſue our projects, and our devices towards my Lady Annabella; go to, ther's a conceit newly landed; harck I ſtand in good reputation with him, and therefore may the better cheat him: Captaine, take a few inſtructions from me.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: What monies I have is at your diſpoſing, and upon twelve I will meete you at the Pallace with it.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I wil there expect you, and ſo I take my leave. Exit

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: You apprehend me?

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Why do ye think I am a dunce?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Not a dunce Captaine, but you might give me leave to miſdoubt that pregnancy in a Souldier, which is proper and hereditary to a Courtier; but proſequute it, I wil both ſecond, and give credit to it. Good Moun|ſier Montague, I would your whole revenues lay within the circuit of mine armes, that I might as eaſily beſtow, or reſtore it unto you as my curteſie.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: My zealous wiſhes ſir, do accompany his for your good fortunes.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Believe it ſir, our affection towards you is a ſtrong band of friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: To which I ſhall moſt willingly ſeale. But be|lieve me Gentlemen in a broken eſtate, the bond of friendſhip oft is forfeited, but that it is your free and in|genuous nature to renew it.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Sir, I wil amply extend my ſelf to your uſe, and am very zealouſly afflicted as not one of your leaſt friends for your croocked fate; But let it ſeiſe you with any dejection, you have as I hear a ſufficient competency left, which wel diſpoſed may erect you as high in the worlds account as ever.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
I cannot live to hope it, much leſſe injoy it, nor
is it any part of my endeavour; my ſtudy is to render e|very man his own, and to containe my ſelf within the limits of a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: I have the grant of an Office given me by ſome noble favorites of mine in Court, there ſtands but a ſmall matter between me and it, if your ability be ſuch to lay down the preſent ſum, out of the love I bear you, before any other man, it ſhall be confirmed yours.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: I have heard you often ſpeak of ſuch a thing; if it be aſſur'd to you I wil gladly deale in it that por|tion I have, I would not hazard upon one courſe, for I ſee the moſt certaineſt is incertain.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Having money ſir, you could not light upon men that could give better direction; there is at this time a friend of mine upon the Seas; to be plain with you, he is a Pyrate, that hath wrote to me to work his fre|dom, and by this Gentlemans meanes, whoſe acquain|tance is not ſmall at Court; we have the word of a wor|thy man for it, only there is ſome money to be ſuddainly disburſt, and if your happineſſe be ſuch to make it up you ſhall receive treble gaine by it, and good aſſurance for it.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Gentlemen out of the weakneſſe of my eſtate you ſeem (to have ſome knowledge of my breſt) that wood if it were poſſible advance my declined fortunes, to ſatisfie all men of whom I have had credit, and I know no way better then theſe which you propoſe; I have ſome money ready under my command, ſome part of it is al|ready promiſ'd, but the remainder is yours to ſuch uſes as are propounded.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Appoint ſome certain place of meeting, for theſe affaires requires expedition.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: I wil make it my preſent buſineſſe: at twelve, I am to meet Mallicorne the Marchant at the Pallace, you know him ſir, about ſome negotiation of the ſame nature, there I wil be ready to tender you that money, upon ſuch conditions as wee ſhall conclude off.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: The care of it be yours, ſo much as they affaire concernes you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Your caution is effectuall, and till then I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Good Mr Montague. Exit

div.stage: Whithin a elamor, down with their weapons. Enter Longavile and Dubois, their ſwords drawn, ſervants and others between them.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Nay Gentlemen what meane you pray be quiet, have ſome reſpect unto the houſe.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: A treacherous ſlave.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Thou doſt revile thy ſelf baſe Longavile.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: I ſay thou art a villaine and a corrupt one, that haſt ſome ſeaven years fed on thy maſters trencher, yet never bredſt good bloud towards him: for if, thou hadſt have a ſounder heart.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: So ſir, you can uſe your tongue ſomething nim|bler then your ſword.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Wood you cood uſe your tongue well of your Maſter, friend you might have better imployment for your ſword.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: I ſay againe and I wil ſpeak it loud and often, that Orleans is a noble Gentleman with whom Amiens is to light to poyſe the ſcale.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: He is the weaker for taking of a prayſe out of thy mouth.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: This hand ſhall ſeale his merit at thy heart.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Part them my maſters part them.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Part them ſir, why do you not part them, you ſtand by with your ſword in your hand, and cry part 'em.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Why you muſt know my friend my cloaths are better then yours, and in a good ſuit, I do never uſe to part any body.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: And it is diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: I marry is it Captaine.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Duboies though this place priviledge thee, know where next we meet, the bloud which at thy heart flowes drops at thy feet.

div.stage: Enter Amience in haſt, his ſword drawne.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: I would not ſpend it better then in this quarrell, and on ſuch a hazard.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: What uprores this, muſt my name here be queſti|on'd in Tavern brawels, and by affected Ruffins?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Not we indeed ſir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Fear cannot make me ſhrink out of your fury, though you were greater then your name doth make you, I am one, and the oppoſer; if your ſwoln rage have ought in mallice to inforce expreſſe it.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: I ſeek thee not nor ſhalt thou ever gaine
That credit, which a blow from me wood give thee,
By my —I more deteſt that fellow
Which took my part then thee, that he durſt offer
To take my honour in his feeble armes,
And ſpend it in a drinking room; which way went he?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: That way ſir, I wood you wood after for I do fear we ſhall have ſome more ſcuffling.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Ile follow him, and if my ſpeed o're take him,
I ſhall ill thank him for his forwardneſſe. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: I am glad he's gon, for I do not love to ſee a ſword drawn in the hand of a man that lookes ſo furious, ther's no jeſting with edge tooles, how ſay you Captaine?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I Say tis better jeſting then to be in earneſt with them. Enter Orleance.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: How now? what's the difference? they ſay there have bin ſwords drawn, and in my quarrell, let me know that man, whoſe love is ſo ſincere to ſpend his bloud for my ſake, I will bounteouſly requite him.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: We were all of your ſide, but there he ſtands be|gun it.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: What's thy name?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Give me thy hand, thou haſt receaved no hurt?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Not any, nor wear this body ſtuck full of wounds, I ſhould not count them hurts, being taken in ſo honorable a cauſe as the defence of my moſt worthy Lord.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: The dedication of thy love to me requires my ample bounty, thou art mine, for I do finde thee made unto my purpoſes. Mounſieur Laverdine, pardon my neg|lect I not obſerved you, and how runs rumour.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Why, it runs my Lord like a foot man without a cloak, to ſhow that what's once rumour'd it cannot be hidde.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: And what ſay the rable, am not I the ſubject of their talk?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Troth my Lord the common mouth ſpeakes foule words.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Of me, for turning away thy wife do they not?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Faith the men do a little murmer at it and ſay, 'tis an ill preſident in ſo great a man, marry the women they rayle, out right.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Out upon them rampallions Ile keepe my ſelfe ſafe enough out of their fingers, but what ſay my prity
Jelly compoſed gallant that cenſure every thing more deſperate then it is dangerous; what ſay they?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Marry they are laying wagers, what death you ſhall die; one offers to lay five hundred pounds; And yet he had but a groat about him, & that was in two two-pences too to any man that wo'd make it up a ſhilling; that you were kil'd with a Piſtoll charg'd with white Powder; another offerd to pawne his ſoule for five ſhil|lings, and yet no body wo'd take him, that you were ſtab'd to death and ſho'd die with more wounds then Ceſar.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: And who ſho'd be the Butchers that ſho'd do it? Montague and his aſſociates?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: So tis conjectured.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: And believe it, ſweet Prince, it is to be feared, and therefore prevented.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: By turning his purpoſe on himſelf, were not that the way?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: The moſt direct path for your ſafety. For where doth danger ſit more furious then in a deſperate man?

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: And being you have declined his meanes, you have increaſt his malice.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Beſides the generall report that ſteems in every mans breath, and ſtaines you all over with infamy, that Time the devourer of all things cannot eat out.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: I, for that former familiarity, which he had with your Lady.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Men ſpeak it as boldly as words of complement; good morrow, good even, or God ſave you ſir, are not more uſuall; if the word cuckold had been written upon your forehead in great Capitall Letters, it could not have been dilated with more confidence.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: He ſhall not ſleepe another night, I will have his blood, though it be required at my hands again.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip may, and without hazzarding your own perſon; he's a Gentleman in whoſe looks I ſee a reſolution to perform it.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Let his Lordſhip give me but his honourable word for my life, Ile kill him as he walks.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Or piſtoll him as he ſits at meat.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Or at game.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Or as he is drinking.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Any way.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Wot thou? call what is mine thine own, thy re|putation ſhall not be brought in queſtion for it, much|leſſe thy life; it ſhall be namd a deed of valour in thee, not murder: Farewell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: I need no more encouragement, it is a worke I will perſwade my ſelfe that I was borne to.

sp.speaker: Laver.
sp.p: And you may perſwade your ſelfe to that you ſhall be ſav'd by it, being that it is for his honourable Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: But you muſt yield me means, how, when and where.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: That ſhall be bur taskes;
Nay more, we will be agents with thee:
This houre we are to meet him, on the receipt of certain moneys,
Which indeed we purpoſe honeſtly to cheat him of,
And that's the many cauſes I wo'd have him ſlain,
Who works with ſafety makes a double gain. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Stay ſir, I have took ſome pains to overtake you.
—You name is Longaville?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: I have the word of many honeſt men for't, I crave your Lordſhips pardon, your ſudden apppehenſion on my ſteps made me to frame an anſwer unwitting and unworthy your reſpect.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Doe you know me?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: I know not you; nor am I well pleaſed to make this time, as the affaire now ſtands, the induction of your acquaintance; you are a fighting fellow?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: How my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: I thinke I too much grace you; rather you are a fellow dares not fight, but ſpet and puffe and make a noyſe whilſt your trembling hand drawes out your Sword, to lay it upon Andirons, ſtooles or tables, rather then on a man.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Your honour may beſt ſpeake this; yet— with little ſafety, if I thought it ſerious.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Come, you are a merry braggart, and you have given me cauſe to tell you ſo: what weakneſſe have you ever ſeen in me to prompt your ſelfe, that I could need your helpe, or what other reaſons could induce you to it? you never yet had a meales meat from my Table, nor as I remember from my Wardrop any caſt Suite.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Tis true, I never durſt yet have ſuch a ſervice ſpirit, to be the minion of a full ſwolne Lord; but alwaies did deteſt ſuch ſlavery: a meales meat, or a caſt ſute? I wo'd firſt eate the ſtones, and from ſuch rags the dunghils does afford pick me a garment.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: I have miſtook the man, his reſolute ſpirit
Proclaimes him generous, he has a noble heart
As free to utter good deeds as to act them;
For had he not been right, and of one piece,
He would have crumpled, curled, and ſtruck himſelfe
Out of the ſhape of man into a ſhaddow.
But prethee tell me, if no ſuch fawning hope
Did lead thee on to hazzard life for my ſake;
What was it that incited thee?
Tell me; ſpeak it without the imputation of a Sicophant.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Your own deſert, and with it was joyn'd the unfained friendſhip that I judged you ever held unto my former Lord.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: The noble Montague?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Yes, the noble and much injured Montague.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: To ſuch a man as thou art, my heart ſhall be
A Casket: I will lock thee up there,
And eſteem thee as a faithfull friend,
The richeſt Jewell that a man enjoyes;
And being thou didſt follow once my friend,
And in thy heart ſtill doſt, not with his fortunes caſting him off,
Thou ſhalt goe hand in hand with me, and ſhare
As well in my ability as love; tis not my end
To gaine men for my uſe, but a true friend. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: There's no ſuch thriving way to live in grace,
As to have no ſence of it; his backe nor belly
Shall not want warming that can practiſe me miſchiefe;
I walke now with a full purſe, grow high and wanton,
Prune and briske my ſelfe in the bright ſhine
Of his good Lordſhips favours; and for what vertue?
For faſhioning my ſelfe a murderer.
O noble Montague, to whom I owe my heart,
With all my beſt thoughts, tho my tongue have promiſd
To exceed the malice of thy deſtiny,
Never in time of all my ſervice knew I
Such a ſinne tempt thy bounty; thoſe that did feed
Upon thy charge had merit or elſe need.

div.stage: Enter Laverdine and Lapoope, with diſguiſes.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Duboys, moſt proſperouſly met.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: How now? will he come this way.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: This way, immediately; therefore thy aſſiſtance, deere Duboys.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: What have you cheated him of the money you ſpoke of?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Fough, as eaſily as a filly Countrey wench of her maydenhead; we had it in a twinkling.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Tis well Captaine, let me helpe you, you muſt be our leader in this action.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Tut, feare not, Ile warrant you if my Sword hold, we'l make no ſweating ſickneſſe of it.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Why that's well ſaid, but let's retire a little, that we may come on the more bravely; this way, this way.

div.stage: Enter Montague in the hands of three Officers, and three Creditors.

sp.speaker: 1 Cre.
sp.p: Officers look to him, and be ſure you take good ſecurity before he part from you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Why but my friends, you take a ſtrange courſe with me; the ſums I owe you are rather forgetfulneſſe they are ſo ſlight, then want of will or honeſty to pay you.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.p: I ſir, it may be ſo; but we muſt be paid, and we will be paid before you ſcape: we have wife and chil|dren, and a charge, and you are going down the wind, as a man may ſay; and therefore it behooves us to looke to't in time.

sp.speaker: 2 Cred.
sp.p: Your cloak here wo'd ſatisfie me, mine's not above a three pound matter, beſides the arreſt.

sp.speaker: 3 Cred.
sp.p: Faith and mine is much about that matter too; your Girdle and Hangers, and your Beaver, ſhall be ſuf|ficient baile for't.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.p: If you have ever a plain black ſute at home, this Silken one, with your Silke-ſtockings, Garters, and Roſes ſhall pacifie me too; for I take no delight, if I have a ſufficient pawne, to caſt any Gentleman in priſon; therefore tis but an untruſſing matter, and you are free, we are no unreaſonable creatures you ſee; for mine own part, I proteſt I am loth to put you to any trouble for ſecurity.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Is there no more of you? he wo'd next demand my skinne.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.p: No ſir, here's no more of us, nor do any of us demand your skin, we know not what to doe with it: but it may be if you ow'd your Glover any money, he knew what uſe to make of it.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Ye dregs of baſeneſſe, vultures amongſt men,
That tyer upon the hearts of generous ſpirits.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.p: You doe us wrong ſir, we tyre no generous ſpirits, we tyre nothing but our hackneys.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: But here comes one made of another piece;
A man well meriting that free born name
Of Citizen; welcome my deliverer, I am falne
Into the hands of blood-hounds, that for a ſum
Leſſer then their honeſties, which is nothing,
Wo'd teare me out of my skin.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why ſir, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: 1 Cre.
sp.p: Why ſir, the matter is, that we muſt have our money, which if we cannot have, we'l ſatisfie our ſelves with his carcaſſe, and be payd that waies: you had as good ſir not have been ſo peremptory. Officer, hold faſt.

sp.speaker: 1 Offi.
sp.p: The ſtrenuous fiſt of vengeance now is clutcht; therefore feare nothing.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: What may be the debt in groſſe?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Some forty Crowns, nay rather not ſo much, tis quickly caſt.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Tis ſtrange to me, that your eſtate ſho'd have ſo low an ebbe, to ſticke at ſuch ſleight ſums: why my friends, you are too ſtrict in your accounts, and call too ſudden on this Gentleman, he has hopes left yet to pay you all.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.p: Hopes? I marry bid him pay his friends with hopes, and pay us with currant Coyne: I knew a gallant once that fed his creditors ſtill with hopes, and bid 'em they ſho'd feare nothing, for he had 'em tyed in a ſtring; and truſt me ſo he had indeed, for at laſt he and all his hopes hopt in a haltar.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Good ſir, with what ſpeed you may free out the company of theſe ſlaves, that have nothing but their names to ſhow 'em men.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: What wo'd you wiſh me do ſir? I proteſt I ha' not the preſent ſumme (ſmall as it is) to lay down for you; and for giving my word, my friends no latter then yeſternight made me take bread and eate it, that I ſho'd not do it for any man breathing ith' world; therefore I pray bold me excuſed.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: You doe not ſpeake this ſeriouſly?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: As ever I ſaid my prayers, I proteſt to you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: What may I think of this?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Troth ſir thought is free for any man; we abuſe our betters in it, I have done it my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Truſt me, this ſpeech of yours doth much amaze me, pray leave this language, and out of that ſame ſum you lately did receive of me, lay down as much as may diſcharge me.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: You are a merry man ſir, and I am glad you take your croſſes ſo temperately; fare you well ſir, and yet I have ſomething more to ſay to ye, a word in your eare I pray; to be plaine with you I did lay this plot to arreſt you to enjoy this money I have of yours, with the more ſafety. I am a foole to tell you this now; but in good faith I could not keepe it in. And the money wo'd a done me little good elſe. An honeſt Citizen cannot wholly enjoy his own wife for you, they grow old be|fore they have true uſe of them, which is a lamentable thing, and truely much hardens the hearts of us Citi|zens againſt you: I can ſay no more, but am heartily ſorry for your heavineſſe, and ſo I take my leave.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.l: Officers take hold on him againe, for Mounſier
Mallycorne will doe nothing for him I perceive.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Nay come my maſters, leave dauncing of the old meaſures, and let's aſſault him bravely.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: By no means; for it goes againſt my ſtomacke to kill a man in an unjuſt quarrell.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: It muſt needs be a clog to a mans conſcience all his life time.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: It muſt indeed Captaine: beſides doe ye not ſee he has gotten a guard of friends about him, as if he had ſome knowledge of our purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Had he a guard of Devils as I think them little better, my Sword ſhould doe the meſſage that it came for.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: If you will be ſo deſperate, the blood lie upon your own neck, for we'l not meddle in't.

div.stage: Duboys runs upon Montague, and ſtrugling yeelds him his Sword; the Officers draw, Laverdine and La-poope in the ſcuffling retire, Montague chaſeth them off the Stage, himſelfe wounded.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: I am your friend and ſervant,
Struggle with me and take my Sword;
Noble ſir make your way, you have ſlaine an Officer.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Some one of them has certainly
Requited me; for I do loſe much blood.

sp.speaker: 1 Offic.
sp.p: Udſprecious, we have loſt a brother, purſue the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: 2 Offic.
sp.p: Ile not meddle with him: you ſee what comes on't; beſides I know he will be hang'd ere he be taken.

sp.speaker: 1 Offic.
sp.p: I tell thee yeoman he muſt be taken ere he be hanged; he is hurt in the guts, run afore therefore and know how his wife will rate his Sawſiges a pound.

sp.speaker: 3 Offic.
sp.p: Stay brother, I may live, for ſurely I finde i'm but hurt in the leg a dangerous kick on the ſhin-bone.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Madam Lamira, Madam le Orleans, Veramour.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You ſee Lady
What harmleſſe ſports ous Countrey life affords;
And though you meet not here with City dainties,
Or Courtly entertainment, what you have
Is free and hearty.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: Madam, I finde here
What is a ſtranger to the Court, content,
And receive curteſies done for themſelves,
Without an expectation of returne,
Which binds me to your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Oh your love;
My homely houſe built more for uſe then ſhew
Obſerves the Golden mean equally diſtant
From glittering pompe, and ſordid avarice;
For Maskes we will obſerve the workes of nature
And in the place of viſitation read.
Our Phyſick ſhall be wholſome walkes, our viandes,
Nouriſhing not provoking: for I finde
Pleaſures are tortures, that leave ſtings behind.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: You have a great eſtate.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: A competency
Sufficient to maintaine me and my ranke,
Nor am I, I thank Heaven, ſo Courtly bred
As to imploy the utmoſt of my Rents
In paying Tailors for phantaſtick Roabes;
Or rather then be ſecond in the faſhion,
Eate out my Officers and my Revenues
With grating uſury; my back ſhall not
Be the baſe on which your ſoothing Citizen
Erects his Summer-houſes; nor on the other ſide
Will I be ſo penuriouſly wiſe,
As to make money (thats my ſlave) my Idoll,
Which yet to wrong, merits as much reproof,
As to abuſe our ſervant.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: Yet with your pardon
I thinke you want the Crown of all contentment.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: In what good Madam?

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: In a worthy husband.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: — It is ſtrange the galley-ſlave ſhould praiſe
His Oare, or ſtroakes; or you, that have made ſhipwracke
Of all delight upon this Rock cal'd marriage,
Should ſing Encomions o't.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: Madam, though one fall
From his horſe and breake his neck, will you
Conclude from that it is unfit to ride?
Or muſt it follow, becauſe Orleance
My Lord's pleaſed to make his paſſionate triall
Of my ſuſpected patience, that my brother,
(Were he not ſo, I might ſay, worthy Amiens)
Will imitate his ills, that cannot fancy
What's truely Noble in him?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I muſt grant
There's as much worth in him as can be lookt for
From a young Lord, but not enough to make
Me change my golden liberty and conſent
To be a ſervant to it, as wives are
To the Imperious humors of their Lords:
Me thinks I'm well, I riſe and goe to bed
When I thinke fit, eate what my appetite
Deſires without controle, my ſervants ſtudy
Is my contentment, and to make me merry
Their fartheſt ayms; my ſleeps are enquired after,
My riſing up ſaluted with reſpect:
Command and liberty now waite upon
My Virgin ſtate; what would I more? change all,
And for a husband? no; theſe freedomes die,
In which they live with my Virginity;
Tis in their choice that's rich to be a wife,
But not being yoakt to chuſe the ſingle life.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: How like you the Countrey?

sp.speaker: Ʋer.
sp.p: I like the ayre of it well Madam, and the rather becauſe as on Iriſh Timber your Spiders will not make his web, ſo for ought I ſee yet your Cheater, Pander, and Informer being in their diſpoſitions too foggy for this piercing climate, ſhun it, and chooſe rather to walk in miſts in the City.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Who did you ſerve firſt boy?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: A rich Merchants widdow, and was by her pre|ferred to a young Court-lady.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.p: And what difference found you in their ſer|vice?

sp.speaker: Ʋer.
sp.p: Very much: for looke how much my old City Madam gave to her-young viſitants, ſo much my Lady received for her hoary Court-ſervants.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: And what made you to leave her?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: My father (Madam) had a deſire to have me a tale-man, took me from thence.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Well, I perceive you inherit the wag, from your father.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Doves beget Doves; and Eagles, Eagles, Madam: A Citizen here, tho left never ſo rich, ſeldome at the beſt proves a Gentleman: the ſonne of an Advocate, tho dub'd like his father, will ſhew a reliſh of his diſcent, and the fathers thriving practice, as I have heard: ſhe that of a Chambermayd is metamorphoſed into a Ma|dam, will yet remember how oft her daughter by her mother ventured to lie upon the ruſhes before ſhe could get in that which makes many Ladies.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.p: But what think you of your late Maſter?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Oh Madam — Sigh.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Why doe you ſigh? you are ſorry that you left him,
He made a wanton of you.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Not for that:
Or if he did, for that my youth muſt love him.
Oh pardon me, if I ſay liberty
Is bondage, if compared with his kind ſervice;
And but to have power now to ſpeake his worth
To its deſert; I ſhould be well content
To be an old man when his praiſe were ended:
And yet, if at this inſtant you were pleaſed,
I ſhould begin, the livery of age
Would take his lodging upon this head
Ere I ſhould bring it to a period.
In briefe he is a man (for God forbid
That I ſhould ever live to ſay he was
Of ſuch a ſhape as would make one beloved,
That never had good thought;) and to his body
He hath a mind of ſuch a conſtant temper
In which vertues throng to have a room:
Yet 'gainſt this noble Gentleman, this Montague,
For in that name I comprehend all goodneſſe,
Wrong, and the wreſted law, falſe witneſſes,
And envy ſent from hell, have roſe in Armes,
And tho not pierced, battered his honourd ſhield.
What ſhall I ſay? I hope you will forgive me,
That if you were but pleas'd to love,
I know no Juno worthy ſuch a Jove.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Tis well yet that I have the ſecond place
In your affection: From whence?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: From the Lord Amiens, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Tis welcome, though it beare his uſual language:
I thought ſo much, his love-ſuit ſpeake his health.
What's he that brought it?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: A Gentleman of good ranke, it ſeems.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Receiving entertainment in your houſe
Sorting with his degree.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Tis well.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: He waites your Ladiſhips pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: He ſhall not waite long:
Ile leave you for a while; nay ſtay you boy,
Attend the Lady. Exeunt Lam. Charl.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Would I might live once
To waite on my poore Maſter.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: That's a good boy:
This thankfulneſſe looks lovely on thy forehead,
And in it, as a book, me thinks I read
Inſtructions for my ſelfe, that am his debtor,
And wo'd do much that I might be ſo happy
To repaire that which to our griefe is ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: It were a worke a King might glory in,
If he ſaw with my eyes: If you pleaſe Madam,
For ſure to me you ſeem to me unapt to walke,
To ſit, although the churliſh Birds deny
To give us muſicke in this grove, where they
Are prodigall to others: Ile ſtrain my voyce
For a ſad Song, the place is ſafe and private.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: Twas my deſire; begin good Viramour.

div.stage: Muſick a Song, at the end of it enter Montague fainting, his Sword drawn.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: What's he Viramour?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: A goodly perſonage.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Am I yet ſafe? or is my flight a dream?
My wounds and hunger tell me that I wake:
Whither have my feares borne me? no matter where,
Who hath no place to goe to, cannot erre:
What ſhall I doe? cunning calamity
That others groſſe wits uſes to refine,
When I moſt need it duls the edge of mine.

sp.speaker: L O●l.
sp.l: Is not this Montagues voyce?

sp.speaker: V●●
sp.l: My Maſters? fie.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: What ſound was that, piſh,
Feare makes the wretch think every leafe oth' Jury:
What courſe to live, beg? better men have done it,
But in another kind: ſteale? Alexander
Though ſtiled a Conquerour, was a proud thiefe
Though he robd with an Army; fie how idle
Theſe meditations are: though thou art worſe
Then ſorrows tongue can ſpeak thee, thou art ſtill
Or ſhouldſt be, honeſt Montague.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: Tis too true.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Tis he: what villaines hands did this? oh that my fleſh
Were Balme; in faith ſir, I would plucke it off
As readily as this; pray you accept
My will to doe you ſervice: I have heard
The Mouſe once ſav'd the Lyon in his need,
As the poore Scarab ſpild the Eagles ſeed.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: How do you?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: As a forſaken man.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: Do not ſay ſo, take comfort,
For your misfortunes have been kind in this,
To caſt you on a hoſpitable ſhoare,
Where dwels a Lady—

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: She to whom, good Maſter,
You prefer'd me.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: In whoſe houſe, whatſoere
Your dangers are, Ile undetake your ſafety.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I feare that I am purſued, and doubt that I
In my defence have kild an Officer.

sp.speaker: Ʋir.
sp.l: Is that all? there's no law under the Sunne
But will I hope confeſſe, one drop of blood
Shed from this arme is recompence enough
Though you had cut the throats of all the Catchpoles
In France, nay in the world.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I would be loth
To be a burthen, or feed like a drone
On the induſtrious labour of a Bee,
And baſer far I hold it to owe for
The bread I eate, what's not in me to pay;
Then ſince my full fortunes are declined,
To their low ebb Ile faſhion my high mind.
It was no ſhame to Hecuba to ſerve
When Troy was fired: ift be in your power
To be a means to make her entertainment,
And far from that I was; but to ſupply
My want with habit fit for him that ſerves,
I ſhall owe much to you.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: Leave that care to me.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Good ſir, leaue on my ſhoulder; helpe good Ma|dam ● oh that I were a horſe for halfe an houre, that I might carry you home on my backe: I hope you wil love me ſtill?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Thou doſt deſerve it boy, that I ſhould live
To be thus troubleſome.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: Good ſir, tis none.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Trouble moſt willingly; I would be changd
Like Apuleius, weare his Aſſes eares,
Provided I might ſtill this burthen beare.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: Tis a kind boy.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I finde true proofe of it. Exeunt:

div.stage: Enter Amiens and Longeville with a Paper.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: You'l carry it.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: As I live although my packet were like Bellero|phons, what have you ſeen in me or my behaviour ſince your favours ſo plentifully ſhowed upon my wants, that may beget diſtruſt of my performance?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Nay, be not angry, if I entertained
But the leaſt ſcruple of your love, or courage,
I would make of one which my ſtate
Should do me right in this, nor can you blame me
If in a matter of ſuch conſequence
I am ſo importunate.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Good my Lord tell me, prevent your further conjurations
To rayſe my ſpirit, I know this is a challenge
To be delivered unto Orleance hand,
And that my undertaking ends not there,
But I muſt be your ſecond, and in that
Not alone ſearch your enemy, meaſure weapons,
But ſtand in all your hazzards, as our blouds
Ran in the ſelf ſame veines, in which if I
Better not your opinion, as a limbe
That's putrifyed and uſeleſſe, cut me off,
And underneath the Gallons bury it.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: At full you underſtand me, and in this
Binde me and what's mine to you and yours,
I wil not ſo much wrong you as to adde
One ſylable more, let it ſuffice I leave
My honor to your guard: and in that prove
You hold the firſt place in my heart and love. Exit Ami.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: The firſt place in a Lords affection? very good; and how long doth that laſt? perhaps the changing of ſome three ſhirts in the Tennis Court; wel it were very neceſſary that an order were taken (if it were poſſible,) that younger brother, might have more wit, or more money: for now how ever the foole hath long bin put upon him that inherits his revenew hath brought him a ſpunge, and wip't off the imputation, and for the un|derſtanding of the younger, let him get as much rhe|torick as he can to grace his language.
They wil ſee he ſhall have gloſſe little enough to ſet out his barck; ſtand Dubois look about all ſafe.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Approach not neer me but with reverence
Lawrell and adorations, I have done more then deſerve a 1●0 thanks.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: How now what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: With this hand only aided by this brain,
Without an Orpheus Harp redeem'd from hels
Three headed Porter, our Euridice.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Nay prithee ſpeak ſence, this is like the ſtale brag|gart in a Play.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Then in plaine Proſe thus, and with as little action as thou canſt deſire, the three headed Porter, were three unexorable Catch-poles out of whoſe jawes with out the help of Orpheus Harp, baite or bribe, for thoſe too ſtringes, makes the Muſique that mollifies thoſe flinty furies, I reſcued our Euridice, I meane my old Maſter Montague.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: And is this all, a poor reſcue, I thought thou hadſt reverſt the judgement for his overthrow, in his ſute, or wrought upon his adverſary Orleance, taken the ſhape of a Ghoſt, frighted his mind into diſtraction, and for the appeaſing of his conſcience forc'd him to make reſtitution of Montagues Lands, or ſuch like reſcued; ſlight I would have hired Crohi●ture for two Carde|kues to have done ſo much with his whip.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: You wood ſir, and yet tis more then three on their foot-cloathes durſt do for a ſworne Brother, in a Coach.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Beſides what proofs of it, for ought I know this may be a trick, I had rather have him a Priſoner, where I might viſit him, and do him ſervice, then not at all, or I know not where.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Well ſir, the end wil ſhew it, what's that a chal|lenge?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Yes, wher's Orleance? though we fight in jeſt he muſt meet with Amiens in earneſt, —fall off, we are diſcovered; my horſe garcon ha'.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Were it not in a houſe and in his preſence,
To whom I owe all duty—

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: What would it do? prate as it do's? but be as far from ſtricking as he that owes it Orleans.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I think thou art his Porter,
Set here to anſwer creditors, that his Lordſhip
Is not within or takes the diet. I am ſent,
And wil grow here untill I have an anſwer,
Not to demand a debt of money, but
To call him to a ſtrict account for wrong
Done to the honors of a Gentleman,
Which nothing but his heart-bloud ſhall waſh off.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Shall I hear this?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: And more, that if I may not
Have acceſſe to him, I will ſix this here
To his diſgrace and thine.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: And thy life with it.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Then have the coppies of it paſted on poſts,
Like Phamplet titles that ſue to be ſold;
Have his diſgrace talk for Tobacco ſhops,
His picture bafful'd.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: All reſpect away, wer't in a Church—draw both

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: This is the book I pray with.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Forbear upon your lives.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: What are you rous'd? I hope your Lordſhip can read (though he ſtaine not his birth with ſcholler-ſhip) doth it not pleaſe you now? if you are a right Moun|ſier, muſter up the reſt of your attendance, which is a page, a cook, a pander, coach-man, and a foot man, in theſe dayes a great Lords traine, pretending I am un|worthy to bring you a challenge, in ſtead of anſwering it, have me kik't.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: If he does thou deſerv'ſt it.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I dare you all to touch me, I'le not ſtand ſtill,
What anſwer you?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: That thou haſt done to Amience
The office of a faithfull friend which I
Would cheriſh in thee were he not my foe,
How ever ſince on honorable tearmes
He cals me forth, ſay I will meet with him,
And by Dubois ere Sun-ſet make him know
The time and place, my ſwords length, and what ever
Scruple of circumſtance he can expect.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: This anſwer comes unlookt for, far you well,
Finding your temper thus, wood I had ſayd leſſe. Exit.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Now Comes thy love to the teſt.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: My Lord 'twill hold,
And in all dangers prove it ſelfe true gold. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I wil acquaint my Lady with your comming.
Pleaſe you repoſe your ſelves here.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Ther's a teſter, nay now I am a woer I muſt be bountifull.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: If you would have two three-pences for it ſir, To give ſome of your kindred as you ride, I'le ſee if I can get them; we uſe not (tho Servants) to take Bribes. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Then thou art unfit, to be in office either in Court or City.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Indeed corruption is a Tree whoſe branches are of an unmeaſurable length they ſpread every where, and the dew that drops from thence have infected ſome chayres and ſtooles of authority.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Ah Captaine, lay not all the fault upon Officers
you know you can ſhark though you be out of action, witneſſe Montague.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Hang him, hee's ſafe enough; you had a hand in it to and have gained by him; but I wonder you Citi|zens that keep ſo many bookes, and take ſuch ſtrict ac|counts for every farthing due to you from others, re|ſerve not ſo much as a memorandum for the curteſies you receive.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Would you have a Citizen book thoſe? thank|fulnes is a thing we are not ſworn to in our indentures: you may as well urge conſcience.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Talke no more of ſuch vanities.
