Montague is ir|recoverably ſunk, I would we had twenty more to ſend after him; the Snake that would be a Dragon and have wings muſt eate; and what imployes that but this, that in this Canniball age he that would have the ſute of wealth muſt not care—whom he feeds on? and as I have heard no fleſh battens better, then that of a pro|feſt friend; and he that would mount to honour muſt not make dainty to uſe the head of his mother, back of his father, or neck of his brother, for ladders to his preferment; for but obſerve, and you ſhall finde for the moſt part cunning villany ſit at a feaſt as principall gueſt, and Innocent honeſty waite as a contemn'd ſer|vant with a trencher.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: The Ladies.

div.stage: Enter Mountague bare-headed, Lamira, Lady Orleance, Charlo, Veramour, ſalute.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Do yee ſmell nothing?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Not I ſir.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: The carrion of knaves is very ſtrong in my no|ſtrels.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: We came to admire, and finde fame was a niggard
Which we thought prodigall in our report
Before we ſaw you.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Tuſh ſir, this Courtſhip's old.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: Ile fight for thee ſweet wench,
This is my tongue and woes for me?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Good man of War,
Hands of; if you take me it muſt be by ſiege,
Not by an onſet; and for your valour, I
Think that I have deſerved few enemies,
And therefore need it not.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Thou needſt nothing ſweet Lady, but an obſe|quious husband, and where wilt thou finde him, if not in the City: we are true Moſcovits to our Wives, and are never better pleaſed, then when they uſe us as ſlaves, bridle and ſaddle us; have me, thou ſhalt command all my wealth as thine own, thou ſhalt ſit like a Queen in my ware houſe; And my factors at the returne with my ſhips ſhall pay thee tribute of all the rarities of the earth; thou ſhalt wear gold, feed on delicates, the firſt peaſcods-ſtrauberies, grapes, cherries ſhall—

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Be mine; I apprehend what you would ſay,
Thoſe dainties which the City payes ſo dear for,
The Country yeilds for nothing, and as early;
And credit me your far fet viandes pleaſe not
My appetite better then thoſe that are neer hand.
Then for your promis'd ſervice and ſubjection
To all my humors, when I am your wife,
Which as it ſeemes is frequent in the City,
I cannot finde what pleaſure they receive
In uſing there fond husbands like their Maydes;
But of this more hereafter; I accept
Your proffer kindly, and yours; my houſe ſtands open
To entertain you; take your pleaſure in it,
And eaſe after your journey.

sp.speaker: La. Orl.
sp.p: Do you note the boldneſſe of the fellowes?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Alas Madam, a virgin muſt in this be like a lawyer,
And as he takes all fees, ſhee muſt hear all ſuitors; the
One for gaine, the other for her mirth; ſtay with the
Gentlemen, wee'l to the Orchards. Exeunt Lamira, La. Orle. Veram. Charl.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: —what art thou?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: An honeſt man, though poor;
And look they like to monſters, are they ſo rare?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Roſe from the dead.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Do you heare Mounſier Serviture, didſt thou ne|ver heare of one Montague a prodigall gull, that lives about Paris?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: So ſ●r.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: One that after the loſſe of his maine eſtate in a
Law ſute, bought an Office in the Court.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: And ſhould have letters of Mart, to have the Spaniſh treaſure as it came from the Indies; were not thou and he twins? put of thy hat, let me ſee thy fore|head.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Though you take priviledge to uſe your tongues,
I pray you hold your fingers,
'Twas your baſe cozenage made me as I am,
And were you ſome where elſe I would take off
This proud filme from your eyes, that will not tell you,
Know I am Montague.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: I will obſerve this better.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: And art thou he? I wil do thee grace; give me thy hand; I am glad thou haſt taken ſo good a courſe; ſerve God and pleaſe thy Miſtris; if I prove to be thy Ma|ſter as I am very likely, I will do for thee.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Faith the fellow's well made for a ſervingman, and will no doubt carry a chyne of Beefe with good grace.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Prithee be carefull of me in my chamber, I will remember thee at my departure.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: All this I can indure under this roof,
And ſo much owe I her, whoſe now I am,
That no wrong ſhall incenſe me to moleſt
Her quiet houſe; while you continue here,
I will not be aſhamed to do you ſervice
More then to her, becauſe ſuch is her pleaſure.
But you that have broke thrice, and foureteen times
Compounded for two ſhillings in the pound,
Know I dare kick you in your ſhop; do ye hear?
If ever I ſee Paris, though an army
Of muſty Murrions, ruſty brown bils and clubs,
Stand for your guard— I have heard of your tricks,
And you that ſmell of Amber at my charge,
And triumph in your cheat; well I may live
To meet thee, be it among a troop of ſuch
That are upon the faire face of the Court
Like running ulcers, and before thy whore
Trampell upon thee.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: This a language for a livery? take heed, I am a Captaine.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: A Gox-comb are you not? that thou and I
To give proof, which of us dares moſt, were now
In mid'ſt of a rough Sea, upon a piece
Of a ſplit ſhip, where only one might ride, Exit Lamira from the Arras.
I would —but fooliſh anger makes me talke
Like a Player.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Indeed you act a part
Doth ill become you my ſervant; is this your duty?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: I crave your pardon, and wil hereafter be more circumſpect.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p:
Oh the power of a Womans tongue! it had
done more then we three with our ſwords durſt un|dertake: put a madde man to ſilence.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Why Sirra theſe are none of your comrades
To drink with in the celler; one of them
For ought you know may live to be your Maſter.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: Ther's ſome comfort yet.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Here's choyce of three, a wealthy Merchant.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Hem, ſhee's taken, ſhe hath ſpy'd my good Calf,
And many Ladies chuſe their husbands by that.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: A Courtier that's in grace, a valiant Captaine,
And are theſe mates for you? away be gon.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I humbly pray you will be pleaſed to pardon,
And to give ſatisfaction to you Madam.
(Although I break my heart) I will confeſſe
That I have wrong'd them too, and make ſubmiſſion.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: No I'le ſpare that; goe bid the Cook haſte Supper. Exit Mont.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Oh brave Lady thou art worthy to have ſervants, to be commandreſſe of a Family, that knowſt how to uſe and govern it.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: You ſhall have many Miſtreſſes that will ſo miſtake as to take their horſe keepers, and footemen in|ſteed of their Husbands, thou art none of thoſe.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: But ſhe that can make diſtinction of men, and knowes when ſhe hath gallants, and fellowes of rank and quality in her houſe—

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Gallants indeed, if it be the Gallants faſhion
To triumph in the miſeries of a man,
Of which they are the cauſe: one that tranſcends
(In ſpight of all that fortune hath, or can be done)
A million of ſuch things as you, my doores
Stand open to receive all ſuch as wear
The ſhape of Gentlemen, and my gentlier nature
(I might ſay weaker) weighes not the expence
Of entertainment; think you i'le forget yet
What's due unto my ſelfe? do not I know,
That you have dealt with poor Montague, but like
Needy Commanders, cheating Citizens,
And perjured Courtiers? I am much mov'd, elſe uſe not
To ſay ſo much, if you will bear your ſelves
As fits ſuch you would make me think you are,
You may ſtay; if not the way lies before you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: What think you of this Captaine?

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: That this is a baudy houſe, with Pinacles and Turrets, in which this diſguiſed Montague goes to rut grat is, and that this is a landed pandreſſe, and makes her houſe a brothell for charity.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Come, that's no miracle; but from whence derive you the ſuppoſition?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Obſerve but the circumſtance; you all know that in the height of Montagues proſperity, hee did affect and had his love return'd by this Lady Orleans; ſince her divorcement, and his decay of eſtate, it is knowne, they have met not ſo much as his boy is wanting; and that this can be any thing elſe then a meer plot for their night work, is above my imagination to conceive.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Nay it carries probability, let us obſerve it better, but yet with ſuch caution as our prying be not diſcovered: here's all things to be had without coſt, and therefore good ſtaying here.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Nay that's true, I would we might woe her twenty years like Penelopes ſutors; come Laverdine.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: I follow inſtantly, yonder he is.
The thought of this Boy hath much coold my affecti|on to his Lady, and by all conjectures, this is a diſ|guiſed whore; I will try if I can ſearch this Mine. Page—

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Your pleaſure ſir?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Thou art a pritty Boy.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: And you a brave man: now I am out of your debt.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Nay prithy ſtay.

sp.speaker: Ʋer.
sp.p: I am in haſte ſir.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: By the faith of a Courtyer.

sp.speaker: Ʋer.
sp.p: Take heed what you ſay, you have taken a ſtrange Oath.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: I have not ſeene a youth that hath pleaſed me better, I would thou could'ſt like me, ſo far as to leave thy Lady and waite on me, I would maintaine thee in the braveſt Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Though you took them up on truſt, or bought 'em at the brokers.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Or any way: then thy imployments ſhould bee ſo neate and cleanly, thou ſhouldſt not touch a payre of Pantables in a Moneth, and thy lodg|ing—

sp.speaker: Ʋer.
sp.p: Should be in a brothell.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: No, but in mine armes.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: That my be the circle of a Baudy houſe, or worſe.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: I meane thou ſhouldeſt lie with me.

sp.speaker: Ʋer.
sp.p: Lie with you? I had rather lie with my Ladies Monkey; 'twas never a good World ſince our French Lords learned of the Neopolitans; to make their Pages their Bed-fellowes, doth more hurt to the Suburbe Ladies then tweenty dead Vacations; Tis Supper time ſir. Exit Ʋeram.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: I thought ſo, I know by that 'tis a Woman, for becauſe peradventure ſhe hath made tryall of the Monkey, ſhe preferrs him before me, as one unknown; well theſe are ſtanding Creatures, and have ſtrange deſires; And men muſt uſe ſtrange meanes to quench ſtrange fires.

div.head: Scaena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Montague, alone, in meane habit.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Now Montague, who diſcerns thy ſpirit now?
Thy breeding or thy bloud? here's a poor cloud
Ecclipſeth all thy ſplendor; who can reade
In thy pale face, dead eye, or lenten ſhute,
The liberty thy ever giving hand
Hath bought for others, manacling it ſelfe
In gives of parchment indiſſoluble?
The greateſt hearted man ſupplyed with meanes,
Nobility of birth and gentleſt parts,
I though the right hand of his Soveraigne,
If vertue quit her ſeat in his high ſoule,
Glitters but like a Pallace ſet on fire,
Whoſe glory whilſt it ſhines, but ruins him,
And his bright ſhow each houre to aſhes tending
Shall at the laſt be rak't up like a ſparkle,
Unleſſe mens lives and fortunes feede the flame.
Not for my own wants though blame I my Stars,
But ſuffering others to caſt love on me,
When I can neither take nor thankfull be.
My Ladies woman, faire and vertuous
Young as the preſent moneth, ſollicits me
For love and marriage now being nothing worth —

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Oh Maſter, I have ſought you a long hour,
Good faith, I never joyd out of your ſight;
For Gods ſake ſir be merry, or elſe beare
The Buffets of your fortunes with more ſcorn;
Do but begin to raile, teach me the way,
And Ile ſit down and help your anger forth:
I have known you weare a ſuit full worth a Lordſhip,
Give to a man whoſe need nere frighted you
From calling of him friend, five hundred Crowns
Ere ſleep had left your ſences to conſider
Your own important preſent uſes; yet
Since I have ſeen you with a trencher waite,
Voide of all ſcorne, therefore Ile waite on you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Would God thou wert leſſe honeſt.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Would to God you were leſſe worthy: I am even w'ee ſir.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Is not thy Maſter ſtrangely fallen, when thou
Serveſt for no wages, but for charity?
Thou doſt ſurcharge me with thy plenteous love:
The goodneſſe of thy vertue ſhown to me,
More opens ſtill my diſability
To quit thy pains: Credit me loving boy,
A free and honeſt nature may be oppreſt,
Tir'd with curteſies from a liberall ſpirit,
When they exceed his means of gratitude.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: But tis a due in him that to that end
Extends his love or duty.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Little world
Of vertue, why doſt love and follow me?

sp.speaker: Ʋer.
sp.l: I will follow you through all Countries,
Ile run (faſt as I can) by your horſe ſide,
Ile hold your ſtirrop when you doe alight,
And without grudging waite till you returne:
Ile quit offerd meanes, and expoſe my ſelfe
To cold and hunger ſtill to be with you;
Fearleſſe Ile travell through a wilderneſſe,
And when you are weary, I will lay me down
That in my boſome you may reſt your head,
Where whilſt you ſleep, Ile watch that no wild beaſt
Shall hurt or trouble you: and thus we'l breed a ſtory
To make every hearer weep,
When they diſcourſe our fortunes and our loves.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Oh what a ſcoffe might men of Wormes make,
If they did know this boy? but my deſire
Is that thou wouldeſt not (as thou uſeſt ſtill
When like a ſervant I'mong ſervants ſit)
Waite on my Trencher, fill my cups with wine:
Why ſhouldſt thou doe this boy? prethee conſider,
I am not what I was.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Curſt be the day when I forget that Montague was my Lord, or not remember him my Maſter ſtill.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Rather curſe me, with whom thy youth hath ſpent
So many houres, and yet untaught to live
By any worldly qualitie.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Indeed you never taught me how to handle Cards
To cheat and coz in men with oathes and lies;
Thoſe are the wordly qualities to live:
Some of our Scarlet Gallants teach their boyes
Theſe worldly qualities.
Since ſtumbling fortune then leaves vertue thus
Let me leave fortune, ere be vicious.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Oh lad, thy love will kill me.

sp.speaker: Ʋer.
sp.l: In truth, I think in conſcience I ſhall die for you:
Good Maſter weep not, doe you want aught ſir?
Will you have any money? here's ſome Silver;
And here's a little Gold, 'twill ſerve to play,
And put more troubleſome thoughts out of your mind:
I pray ſir take it, Ile get more with ſinging.
And then Ile bring it you; my Lady ga't me,
And — it was not covetouſneſſe,
But I forgot to tell you ſooner on't.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Alaſſe boy, thou art not bound to tell it me,
And leſſe to give it, buy thee Scarfes and Garters,
And when I have money, I will give thee a Sword:
Nature made thee a beauteous Cabinet
To lock up all the godneſſe of the Earth.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: I have loſt my voyce with the very ſight of this Gentlewoman: good ſir ſteale away, you were wont to be a curious avoyder of womens company.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Why boy, thou darſt truſt me any where, darſt thou not?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: I had rather truſt you by a roaring Lyon, then a ravening woman.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Why boy.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Why truly ſhe devoures more mans fleſh—

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: I, But ſhe roares not boy.

sp.speaker: Ʋer.
sp.p: No ſir, why ſhe is never ſilent but when her mouth is full.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Mounſier Montague.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: My ſweet fellow, ſince you pleaſe to call me ſo.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Ah my conſcience ſhe would be pleaſed well e|nough to call you bedfellow: oh Maſter, do not hold her by the hand ſo: a woman is a lyme-buſh, that catcheth all ſhe toucheth.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: I do moſt dangerouſly ſuſpect this boy to be a wench; art thou not one? come hither, let me feele thee.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Why doſt thou pull off thy glove?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Why, to feele whether you be a boy, or no.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Fie boy, goe too, Ile not looke your head, nor combe your locks any more, if you talke thus.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Why, ile ſing to you no more then.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Fie upon't, how ſad you are? a young Gentle|man that was the very Sunne of France.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: But I am in the eclipſe now.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Suffer himſelfe to be over-run with a Lethargy of melancholy and diſcontent! rouze up thy ſpirit, man, and ſhake it off:
sp.l: A Noble ſoule is like a ſhip at Sea,
That ſleepes at Anchor when the Ocean's calme;
But when ſhe rages, and the wind blows high,
He cuts his way with skill and Majeſty.
sp.p: I would turn a foole, or Poet, or any thing, or marry, to make you merry; prethee let's walke: good Veramour leave thy Maſter and me, I have earneſt buſineſſe with him.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Pray doe you leave my Maſter, and me; we were very merry before you came, he does not covet womens companie.
sp.l: What have you to do with him? come ſir will you goe?
And ile ſing to you again:
sp.p: I'faith his mind is ſtronger then to credit womens vows, and too pure to be capable of their loves.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: The boy is jealous; ſweet lad leave us; my Lady call'd for you I ſweare: that's a good child, there's a piece of Gold for thee, go buy a Feather.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p:
There's two pieces for you, do you goe and buy one, or what you will, or nothing ſo you goe. Nay then I ſee you would have me go ſir; why, 'faith I will; now I perceive you love her better then you doe me; but
God bleſſe you whatever you do, or intend; I know you are a very honeſt man. Exit.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Still ſhall I woe thee, whilſt thy eares reply
I cannot, or I will not marry thee?
Why haſt thou drawn the blood out of my cheekes,
And given a quicker motion to my heart?
Oh thou haſt bred a fever in my veines
Call'd love, which no Phyſitian can cure;
Have mercy on a maid whoſe ſimple youth—

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: How your example faireſt teacheth me
A ceremonious Idolatry! kneels.
By all the joy of love I love thee better
Then I or any man can tell another;
And will expreſſe the mercy which thou crav'ſt,
I will forbeare to marry thee: conſider
Thou art natures heire in feature, and thy parents
In faire inheritances; riſe with theſe thoughts,
And look on me; but with a womans eye,
A decayd fellow, voyd of means and ſpirit.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Of ſpirit?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Yes, could I tamely live,
Forget my fathers blood, waite and make legs,
Staine my beſt breeches, with the ſervile drops
That fall from others draughts:

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: This vizard wherewith thou wouldſt hide thy ſpirit
Is perſpective, to ſhew it plainlier.
This under-value of thy life is but
Becauſe I ſhould not buy thee; what more ſpeaks
Greatneſſe of man, then valiant patience,
That ſhrinks not under his fates ſtrongeſt ſtrokes?
Theſe Roman deaths, as falling on a Sword,
Opening of veines, with poyſon quenching thirſt,
(Which we erroneouſly doe ſtile the deeds
Of the heroicke and magnanimous man)
Was dead-eyd cowardiſe, and white cheeke feare,
Who doubting tyranny, and fainting under
Fortunes falſe Lottery, deſperately runne
To death for dread of death; that ſoules moſt ſtout,
That bearing all miſchance, dares laſt it out;
Will you performe your word, and marry me,
When I ſhall call you to't?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I'faith I will.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Who's this alights here?

sp.speaker: Long,
sp.p: With leave faire creature, are you the Lady Mi|ſtris of the houſe?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Her ſervant ſir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I pray then favour me, to inform your Lady, and
Duke Orleans wife,
A buſineſſe of emport awaites 'em here,
And craves for ſpeedy anſwer.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Are you in poſt ſir?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: No, I am in Satin Lady; I would you would be in poſt.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: I will returne. Sweet. Exit.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Honeſt friend, doe you belong to the houſe?
I pray be covered.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Yes Sir, I doe.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Ha, dreamſt thou Longaville? ſure tis not he: ſir
I ſhould know you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: So ſhould I you, but that I am aſham'd.
But though thou knowſt me, prethee Longaville,
Mock not my poverty, pray remember your ſelfe;
Showes it not ſtrangely for thy cloathes to ſtand
Without a hat to mine? mocke me no more.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: She—embroyder me all over ſir,
If ever I began to mocke you yet.
The — on me, why ſhould I weare Velvet
And Silver Lace,—I will teare it off.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Why mad-man?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Put on my Hat? yes, when I am hangd I will:
— I could break my head
For holding eyes that knew not you at firſt:
But time and fortune run your courſes with him,
He'l laugh and ſtorm you, when you ſhew moſt hate.

div.stage: Enter Lamira, Orleans Lady, Laverdine, La Poope, Malycorne, Veramour, Charlot:

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You're a fair Mounſier.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Doe you mocke me Lady?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Your buſineſſe ſir, I mean.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Regard your ſelfe good Mounſier Longueville.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You are too negligent of your ſelfe and place,
Cover your head ſweet Mounſier.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Miſtake me not faire Ladies,
Tis not to you, nor you, that I ſtand bare.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Nay ſweet deere Mounſier, let it not be to us then.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: — a complement.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: And — of manners.
Pray hide your head, your gallants uſe to do't.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: And you your foreheads, why you needful acceſſary raſcals,
That cannot live without your mutuall knaveries,
More then a Bawd, a Pandor, or a Whore
From one another; how dare you ſuſpect
That I ſtand bare to you? what make you here?
Shift your houſe Lady of 'em, for I know 'em,
They come to ſteale Napkins, and your Spoons;
Look to your Silver-bodkin, (Gentlewoman)
Tis a dead utenſil, and Page 'ware your pockets;
My reverence is unto this man, my maſter,
Whom you with proteſtations, and oaths
As high as Heaven, as deep as hell, which would
Deceive the wiſeſt man of honeſt nature,
Have cozned and abus'd; but I may meet you,
And beate you one with t'other.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Peace, no more.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Not a word ſir.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I am ſomething thicke of hearing; what ſaid he?

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: I heare him, but regard him not.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Nor I, I am never angry faſting.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: My love keeps back my duty, nobleſt Lady;
If husband or brother merit love from you,
Prevent their dangers, this houre brings to triall
Their hereto ſleeping hates; by this time each
Within a yerd is of the others heart,
And met to prove their cauſes and their ſpirits
With their impartiall Swords points; haſte and ſave,
Or never meet them more but at the grave.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh my diſtracted heart, that my wrackt honour Should for a brothers, or a husbands life, through thy undoing die.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Amiens engagd; if he miſcarry all my hopes and joys,
I now confeſſe it loudly, are undone:
Caroch, and haſte, one minute may betray
A life more worth then all time can repay.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Hump: Mounſier Laverdine purſues this boy ex|treamly. Captaine what will you doe?

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Any thing but follow to this Sea-ſervice; I am a Sea-captaine you know, and to offer to part 'em, with|out we could do't like water-men with long ſtaves, a quarter of a mile off, might be dangerous.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why then let's retire and pray for 'em, I am re|ſolv'd to ſtop your intent; abus'd more then we have been we cannot be, without they fall to flat beating o'us.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: And that were unkindly done i'faith.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: — but you are the troubleſomeſt Aſſe that ere I met with; retire, you ſmel like a womans chamber, that's newly up, before ſhe have pinſht her vapours in with her cloathes.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: I will haunt thee like thy Grandames ghoſt, thou ſhalt never reſt for me.

sp.speaker: Ʋer.
sp.p: Well, I perceive tis vaine to conceale a ſecret from you: believe it ſir, indeed I am a woman.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Why la; I knew't, this Propheticall tongue of mine never faild me; my mother was halfe a witch, ne|ver any thing that ſhe foreſpake, but came to paſſe: a woman? how happy am I? now we may lawfully come together without feare of hanging; Sweet wench, be gracious, in honourable ſort I woe, no otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Ʋer.
sp.p: Faith the truth is I have loved you long.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: See, ſee.

sp.speaker: Ʋer.
sp.p: But durſt not open it.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: — I think ſo.

sp.speaker: Ʋer.
sp.p: But briefly, when you bring it to the teſt, if there be not one Gentleman in this houſe, wil challenge more intereſt in me, then you can, I am at your diſpoſure.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Oh Fortunatus, I envie thee not
For cap, or pouch, this day Ile prove my Fortune,
In which your Lady doth elect her husband,
Who will be Amiens, 'twill ſave my wedding dinner,
Povera, La-poop and Malicorne: if all faile,
I will turne Citizen, a beauteous wife
Is the horn-booke to the richeſt Tradeſmans life.

div.stage: Enter Duboys, Orleans, Longueville, Amiens, two Lacques, a Page wish two Piſtols.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Here's a good even piece of ground my Lords:
Will you fix here?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Yes any where; Lacquey, take off my ſpurs;
Upon a bridge, a raile but my Swords bredth, upon a battlement,
Ile fight this quarrell.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: O' the ropes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Upon a line.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: So all our Countrie Duels are carried, like a fire-worke on a thred.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Go now ſtay with the horſes, and doe you heare
Upon your lives, till ſome of us come to you,
Dare not to looke this way.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Except you ſee ſtrangers or others that by chance or purpoſe are like to interrupt us.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Then give warning.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Who takes a Sword? the advantage is ſo ſmall,
As he that doubts hath the free leave to chooſe.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Come give me any, and ſearch me; tis not
The ground, weapon, or ſeconds that can make
Oddes in thoſe fatall trials: but the cauſe.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Moſt true, and but it is no time to wiſh
When men are come to do, I would deſire
The cauſe 'twixt us were other then it is;
But where the right is, there prevaile our Swords.
And if my ſiſter have outliv'd her honour,
I doe not pray I may outlive her ſhame.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Your ſiſter Amiens, is a whore, at once.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: You oft have ſpoke that ſence to me before,
But never in this language Orleance;
And when yov ſpoke it faire, and firſt, I told you
That it was poſſible you might be abuſ'd:
But now, ſince you forget your manners, you ſhall finde,
If I tranſgreſſe my cuſtome, you doe lie,
And are a villaine, which I had rather yet
My Sword had prov'd, then I been forc'd to ſpeake:
Nay give us leave, and ſince you ſtand ſo haughtily
And highly on your cauſe, let you and I,
Without engaging theſe two Gentlemen, ſingly determine it.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: My Lord, you'l pardon us.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: I truſt your Lordſhips may not doe us that affront.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: As how?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: We kiſſe your Lordſhips hand, and come to ſerve you here with Swords.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: My Lord, we underſtand our ſelves.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: We have had the honour to be call'd unto the buſineſſe, and we muſt not now quit it on terms.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Not terms of reaſon?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: No, no reaſon for the quitting of our calling.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: True if I be call'd to't I muſt aske no reaſon.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Nor heare none neither, which is leſſe:
It is a favour if my throat be cut,
Your Lordſhip does me; which I never can,
sp.stage: A noiſe within, crying down with their Swords.
sp.l: Nor muſt have hope how to requite: what noiſe,
What cry is that my Lord upon your guard?
Some treachery is a foot.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: O here they are:
My Lord (deare Lady helpe me) helpe me all;
I have ſo woefull intereſt in both,
I know not which to feare for moſt: and yet
I muſt prefer my Lord. Deare brother,
You are too underſtanding, and too Noble
To be offended, when I know my duty,
Though ſcarce my teares will let me ſo to do it.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Out loathed ſtrumpet.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: O my deareſt Lord,
If words could on me caſt the name of whore,
I then were worthy to be loath'd; but know,
Your unkindneſſe cannot make me wicked;
And therefore ſhould leſſe uſe that power upon me.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Was this your art to have theſe actors come,
To make this interlude? withdraw, cold man,
And if thy ſpirit be not frozen up,
Give me one ſtroke yet at thee for my vengeance.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt have ſtroakes, and ſtroakes, thou glorious man,
Till thou breathſt thinner ayre then that thou talkeſt.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: My Lord Count Amiens.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Princely husband.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Whore.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You wrong her impudent Lord; O that I had the bulke
Of thoſe dull men; look how they ſtand, and no man
Will revenge an innocent Lady.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: You hinder it Madam.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: I would hinder you; is there none elſe to kill him?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Kill him Madam? have you learn'd that bad Language? O repent,
And be the motive, rather both kill me.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Then die my infamy.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Hold bloody man.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Art thou their Baſiliske?

sp.speaker: Mont:
sp.p: To ſtrike thee dead, but that thy fate deſerves ſome weightier hand.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Sweet my Lord.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: O here's a plot; you bring your champions with you; the adultreſſe with the adulterer: Out howling—

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Are you her Graces countenance Lady, the
receiver to the poore vicious couple.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Sweet my Lord.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Sweet raſcall, didſt not thou tell me, falſe fellow,
This Montague, here was murdered?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: I did ſo; but he was falſer, and a worthleſſe Lord,
Like thy foule ſelfe, that would have had it ſo.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Orleance tis true, and ſhall be prov'd upon thee.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Thy malice Duke, and this thy wicked nature, are all as viſible as thou; but I borne to contemne thy iniuries, doe know, that though thy greatneſſe may cor|rupt a Jury, and make a Judge afraid, and carry out a world of devils with thy title: yet thou art not quiet at home, thou beareſt about thee that, that doth charge thee, and condemne thee too. The thing that grieves me more, and doth indeed diſpleaſe me, is, to thinke that ſo much baſeneſſe ſtands here to have encountered ſo much honour: Pardon me my Lord what late my paſ|ſion ſpake, when you provok'd my innocence.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Yes doe, O flattery becomes him better then the ſute he weares; give him a new one Amiens.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Orleance, tis here no time nor place, to jeſt or raile
Poorely with you, but I will finde a time to
Whiſper you forth to this or ſome fit place,
As ſhall not hold a ſecond interruption.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I hope your Lordſhips honour, and your life
Are deſtined unto higher hazzards; this is of
A meaner arme.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Yes faith, or none.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: He is not fit to fall by an honeſt Sword,
A Prince and lie!

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: And ſlander, and hire men
To publiſh the falſe rumours he hath made.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: And ſticke 'em on his friends, and innocents.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: And practice againſt their lives after their fames.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: In men that are the matter of all leudneſſe,
Bands, thieves, and cheaters, it were monſtrous.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: But in a man of blood, how more conſpicuous?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Can this be?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: They doe ſlander him.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Hang them, a paire of railing hangbies.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: How? ſtand Orleance; ſtay, give me my Piſtols boy,
Hinder me not, by—
I will kill him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O ſtay his fury,

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Longueville, my friend.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Not for my ſelfe, my Lord, but for mankind,
And all that have an intereſt to vertue,
Or title unto innocence.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Why heare me.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: For juſtice ſake.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: That cannot be.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: To puniſh his wives, your honour, and my Lords wrongs here, whom I muſt ever call ſo; for your loves Ile ſweare, Ile ſacrifice—

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Longaville, I did not thinke you a murtherer before.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: I care not what you thought me.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: By —If thou attempt
His life, thy own is forfeit.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Fooliſh frantick man, the murder will be of us, not him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O God.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: We could have kild him, but we would not take
The juſtice out of fates. —
Singe but a haire of him, thou dieſt.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: No matter, ſhoot.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Villaine.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: My Lord, your ſiſter is ſlaine.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: O hapleſſe and moſt wretched chance.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Standſt thou looking upon the miſchief thou haſt made
Thou Godleſſe man, feeding thy blood-ſhot eyes
With the red ſpectacle, and art not turn'd to ſtone
With horrour? hence and take the wings of thy blacke
Infamy, to carry thee beyond the ſhoot of looks,
Or ſound of curſes, which will purſue thee ſtill:
Thou haſt out-fled all but thy guilt.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: O wiſh it off again, for I am crack'd
Under the burden, and my heart will breake.
How heavy guilt is, when men come to feele
If you could know the mountaine I ſuſtaine
With horror, you would each take off your part,
And more, to eaſe me: I cannot ſtand,
Forgive where I have wrong'd I pray.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Looke to him Montague.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: My Lords and Gentlemen, the Lady is well, but for feare,
Unleſſe that have ſhot her;
I have the worſt on't, that needs would venture
Upon a tricke had like to ha' coſt my guts:
Look to her, ſhe'l be well, it was but Powder
I chargd with, thinking that a guilty man
Would have been frighted ſooner; but I am glad
He's come at laſt.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: How is Byancha? well?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Lives ſhe? ſee ſiſter, doth ſhe breath?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: O Gentlemen, thinke you I can breath,
That am reſtored to the hatefull ſenſe
Of feeling in me my deare husbands death?
O no, I live not; life was that I left;
And what you have cal'd me to, is death indeed;
I cannot weep ſo faſt as he doth bleed.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Pardon me Madam, he is well.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ha my husband.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: I cannot ſpeake whether my joy or ſhame
Be greater, but I thank the Heavens for both.
O look not black upon me, all my friends,
To whom I will be reconciled, or grow unto
This earth, till I have weept a trench
That ſhall be great enough to be my grave,
And I will think them too moſt manly teares,
If they do move your pities: it is true,
Man ſhould do nothing that he ſhould repent;
But if he have, and ſay that he is ſorry,
It is a worſe fault if he be not truly.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: My Lord, ſuch ſorrow cannot be ſuſpected:
Here take your honoured wife, and joyn your hands.
— ſhe hath married you again:
And Gentlemen, I do invite you all,
This night to take my houſe, where on the morrow,
To heighten more the reconciling feaſt,
Ile make my ſelfe a husband and a gueſt. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Well now I am ſure you are mine.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I am ſure I am glad
I have one to own then; you'l finde me honeſt
As theſe daies go, enough; poore without queſtion,
Which beggars hold a vertue; give me meat, and I
Shall do my worke, elſe knock my ſhooes off,
And turn me out again.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: You are a merry fellow.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I have no great cauſe.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Yes thy love to me.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: That's as we make our game.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Why you repent then.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Faith no worſ then I am I cannot be;
Much better I expect not: I ſhall love you,
And when you bid me goe to bed, obey,
Lie ſtill or move, as you ſhall miniſter,
Keep a foure-nobles Nag, and a black
Merling, learn to love Ale, and play at two-hand Iriſh,
And there's then all I aime at.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Nay ſweet fellow, Ile make it ſomething better.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: If you doe, you'l make me worſe:
Now I am poore, and willing to doe wel,
Hold me in that courſe, of all the Kings creatures,
I hate his coyne, keep me from that, and ſave me;
For if you chance out of your houſewifery
To leave a hundred pound or two, beſtow it
In Plum-broth ere I know it, elſe I take it;
Seeke out a hundred men that want this money,
Share it among 'em, they'l cry noble Montague,
And ſo I ſtand again at livery.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: You have pretty fancies ſir, but married once,
This charity will fall home to your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I would it would, I am afraid my looſeneſſe
Is yet ſcarce ſtopt, though it have nought to worke on
But the meere aire of what I have had.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Pretty.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I wonder ſweet heart why you'l marry me,
I can ſee nothing in my ſelfe deſerves it,
Unleſſe the handſome wearing of a band,
For that's my ſtocke now, or a paire of garters,
Neceſſity will not let me looſe.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I ſee ſir a great deale more, a hanſome man, a husband
To make a right good woman truely happy.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Lord, where are my eyes? either you are fooliſh
As wenches once a yeere are, or far worſe,
Extreamly vertuous, can you love a poore man
That relies on cold meat and caſt ſtockings,
One onely ſuit to his backe, which now is mewing?
But what will be the next coate will poſe Triſtram.
If I ſhould leavy from my friends a fortune:
I could not raiſe ten groats to pay the Prieſt now.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Ile do that duty; tis not means nor money
Makes me purſue your love; were your mind bankrupt,
I would never love you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Peace wench, here's my Lady.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Nay never ſhrinke i'th wetting, for my preſence;
D'ee finde her willing Montague?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Willing Madam?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: How dainty you make of it, doe not I know
You two love one another?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Certaine Madam, I thinke ye'ave revelations of theſe matters:
Your Ladyſhip cannot tell me when I kiſt her.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: But ſhe can, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: But ſhe will not Madam;
For when they talke once, tis like fairy-money,
They get no more cloſe kiſſes.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Thou art wanton.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: God knows I need not, yet I would be luſty:
But — my provender ſcarce pricks me.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: It ſhall be mended Montague, I am glad you are grown ſo merry.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: So am I too Madam.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You two will make a pretty hanſome conſort.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Yes Madam, if my fiddle faile me not.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Your Fiddle? why your Fiddle? I warrant thou meaneſt madly:

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Can you blame me? alaſſe I am in love.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Tis very well ſir.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: How long have you been thus?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: How thus in love?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You are very quick ſir: no, I mean thus pleaſant.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: —Ever ſince I was poore.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: A little wealth would change you then.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Yes Lady into another ſuit, but never more
Into another man: Ile bar that mainly,
The wealth I get henceforward ſhal be charm'd
For ever hurting me, Ile ſpend it faſting:
As I live noble Lady there is nothing
I have found directly cures the melancholy,
But want and wedlocke; when I had ſtore of money
I ſimper'd ſometime, and ſpoke wondrous wiſe,
But never laught out-right; now I am empty
My heart ſounds like a bell, and ſtrikes at both ſides.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You are finely temper'd Montague.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Pardon Lady, if any way my free mirth have offended,
Twas meant to pleaſe you: if it prove too ſawſie,
Give it a frown, and I am ever ſilenc'd.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I like it paſſing well; pray follow it:
This is my day of choice, and ſhall be yours too,
Twere pity to delay ye: call to the Steward,
And tell him tis my pleaſure he ſhould give you
500 Crowns: make your ſelfe hanſome Montague,
Let none weare better cloathes, tis for my credit;
But pray be merry ſtill.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: If I be not, and make a foole of twice as many hundreds,
Clap me in Canvas Lady. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I am ſtrangely glad, I have found the myſtery
Of this diſguiſed boy out: I ever truſted
It was a woman, and how happily
I have found it ſo; and for my ſelfe, I am ſure
One that would offer me a thouſand pound now
(And that's a pretty ſum to make one ſtagger)
In ready Godl for this concealment, could not
Buy my hope of her, ſhe's a dainty wench,
And ſuch a one I finde▪ I want extreamly
To bring me into credit: beauty does it.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Say we ſhould all meach here, and ſtay the feaſt, now what can the worſt be? we have plai'd the knaves, that's without queſtion.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: True, and as I take it this is the firſt truth
We told theſe ten yeeres, and for any thing
I know may be the laſt: but grant we are knaves,
Both baſe and beaſtly knaves —

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Say ſo then.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: And likewiſe let it be conſidered, we have wrongd
And moſt maliciouſly, this Gentlewoman,
We caſt to ſtay with, what muſt we expect now?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I there's the point, we would expect good eating.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: I know we would, but we may find good beating.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: You ſay true Gentlemen, and by—
Though I love meat as well as any man,
I care not what he be, if a eate a Gods name;
Such crab-ſauce to my meat wil turn my pallate.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: There's all the hazzard, for the frozen Montague
Has now got ſpring againe, and warmth in him,
And without doubt dares beat us terribly.
For not to mint the matter, we are cowards,
And have and ſhall be beaten when men pleaſe
To call us into cudgelling.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: I feele we are very prone that way.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: The ſonnes of Adam.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: Now here then reſts the ſtate o'th queſtion?
Whether we yeild our bodies for a dinner
To a ſound dog-whip, for I promiſe ye
If men be given to correction,
We can expect no leſſe, or quietly
Take a hard Egge or two, and ten mile hence
Baite in a ditch, this we may do ſecurely;
For to ſtay here about will be all one,
If once our morall miſchiefes come in memory.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: But pray ye hear me, is not this the day
The Virgin Lady doth elect her husband?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: The dinner is to that end.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Very well then, ſay we all ſtay, and ſay we all ſcape this whipping, and be well entertained, and one of us carry the Lady.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: 'Tis a ſeemly ſaying, I muſt confeſſe, but if we ſtay, how fitly
We may apply it to our ſelves (i'th end)
Will aske a Chriſtian feare; I cannot ſee
If I ſay true, what ſpetiall ornaments
Of art or nature, lay aſide our lying
Whoring and drinking, which are no great vertues,
We are endued withall to win this Lady.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Yet women go not by the beſt parts ever; that I have found directly.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Why ſhould we fear then? they chooſe men
As they feed; ſome times they ſettle
Upon a white broth'd face, a ſweet ſmooth gallant,
And him they make an end of in a night;
Sometimes a Gooſe, ſometimes, a groſſer meat,
A rump of beef will ſerve 'em at ſome ſeaſon,
And fill their bellies too: though without doubt
They are great devourers: ſtock fiſh is a diſh,
If it be well dreſt, for the tufneſſe ſake
Wil make the proud'ſt of 'em long and leap for't.
They'l run mad for a pudding ere they'l ſtarve,

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: For my own part I care not, come what can come,
If I be whipt, why ſo be it; if cudgel'd,
I hope I ſhall out live it, I am ſure
'Tis not the hundreth time I have bin ſerv'd ſo,
And yet I thank God I am here.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Here's reſolution.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: A little patience, and a rotten Apple
Cures twenty worſe diſeaſes; what ſay you ſir?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Marry I ſay ſir, if I had bin acquainted
With lamming in my youth, as you have bin
With whipping, and ſuch benefits of nature,
I ſhould do better: as I am, i'le venture,
And if it be my luck to have the Lady,
I'le uſe my fortune modeſtly; if beaten
You ſhall not hear a word, one I am ſure of,
And if the worſt fall ſhe ſhall be my phyſick.
Lets go then, and a merry winde be with us.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Captaine your ſhooes are old, pray put 'em off,
And let one fling 'em after us; be bold ſirs,
And howoſever our fortune fals, lets beare
An equall burden; if there be an odde laſh,
Wee'l part it afterwards.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: I am arm'd at all points. Exeunt

div.stage: Enter foure ſerving in a Banquet.

sp.p: Then my Lady will have a bedfellow to night.
So ſhe ſayes, heaven what a danty armefull ſhall he enjoy that has the launching of her, what a fight ſhee'l make.
I mary boyes, there will be ſport indeed, there will be grapling, ſhe has a murderer lies in her prow, I am affraid will fright his maine maſt Robin.
Who doſt thou think ſhall have her of thy con|ſcience, thou art a wiſe man.
If ſhe go the old way, the way of lot, the longeſt cut ſweeps all without queſtion?
She has loſt a friend of me elſe; what think yee of the Courtier.
Hang him hedgehogge, h'as nothing in him but a piece of Euphues, and twenty dozen of twelve penny riband all about him, he is but one Pedlers ſhop of gloves and garters, pickteeth and pomander.
The Courtier! marry God bleſſe her Steven, ſhe is not mad yet, ſhe knowes that trindle tayle too well, he's creſt falne, and pinbuttock't with leaping Lan|dreſſes.
The Merchant ſure ſhee will not be ſo baſe to have him.
I hope ſo Rohin, hee'l ſell us all to the Moors to make mummy; nor the Captaine.
Who Potgun, that's a ſweet youth indeed, will he ſtay thinke ye?

Yes, without queſtion, and have half din'd too ere the grace be done; he's good for nothing in the world but eating, lying and ſleeping; what other men de|vour in drink, he takes in Pottage, they ſay has bin at Sea, a Herring fiſhing, for without doubt he dares not hayle an Ele-boate, ith way of War.
I think ſo, they would beate him off with Butter.

When he brings in a prize, unleſſe it be Cockles, or Callis ſand to ſcoure with, I'le renounce my five mark a year, and all the hidden art I have in carving, to teach young Birds to whiſtle Walſingham; leave him to the lime boates; now, what think you of the brave Amiens?
That's a thought indeed.
I marry ther's a perſon fit to feed upon a diſh ſo danty, and hee'l do't I warrant him ith nick boyes, has a body world without end.
And ſuch a one my Lady will make no little off; but is not Montague married to day?
Yes faith, honeſt Montague muſt have his bout too.
Hee's as good a lad as ever turnd a trencher; muſt we leave him?
Hee's to good for us Steven, I'le give him health to his good luck to night ith old Beaker, and it ſhall be ſack too.
I muſt have a Garter; and boyes I have beſpoke, a a Poſſet, ſome body ſhall give me thanks for't, 'tas a few toyes in't will raſe commotions in a bed lad.
Away; my Lady. Exeunt

div.stage: Enter Orleance, and his Lady arme in arme, Amiens, Lamira, Charlote, like a Bride, Montague brave, Laverdine, Longavile Dubois, Mallycorn, La-Poope.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Stur your ſelves noble Lords and Gentlemen,
You know your places; many royall welcomes
I give your grace; how lovely ſhewes this change?
My houſe is honor'd in this reconcilement.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Thus Madam muſt you do, my Lady now ſhall ſee
You made a Woman;
And give you ſome ſhort leſſons for your voyage.
Take her inſtructions Lady, ſhe knowes much.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: This becomes you ſir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: My Lord muſt have his will.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Tis all I can do now ſweet heart, faire Lady;
This to your happy choyce brother Amiens,
You are the man I meane it to.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: I'le pledge you.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: And with my heart.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: With all my love I take it.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Noble Lords I am proud ye have done this day,
ſo much content, and me ſuch eſtimation that this hour
(In this poor houſe) ſhall be a league for ever,
For ſo I know ye mean it.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: I do Lady.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: And I my Lord.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Y'ave done a work of honor.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Give me the Cup, where this health ſtops, let
That man be either very ſick, or very ſimple;
Or I am very angry; ſir, to you;
Madam me thinks this Gentleman might ſit to;
He would become the beſt on's.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Pray ſit down ſir, I know the Lady of the feaſt expects not this day ſo much old cuſtom.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Sit down Mountague; nay never bluſh for the matter.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Noble Madam, I have too reaſons againſt it, and I dare not; duty to you firſt, as you are my Lady, and I your pooreſt ſervant; next the cuſtome of this dayes ceremony.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: As you are my ſervant, I may command you then.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: To my life Lady.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Sit down, and here, i'le have it ſo.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Sit down man, never refuſe ſo faire a Ladies offer.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: It is your pleaſure Madam, not my pride,
And I obey; ile pledge yee now my Lord, Mounſier Longavile.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I thank you ſir.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: This to my Lady, and her faire choyce to day, and happineſſe.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Tis a faire health, i'le pledge you though I ſinke for't.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Montague you are too modeſt; come i'le adde a little more wine t'ee, 'twill make you merry, this to the good I wiſh.—

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Honord Lady, I ſhall forget my ſelfe with this great bounty.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: You ſhall not ſir; give him ſome Vine.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: By heaven you are a worthy woman, and that▪
Man is bleſt can come neer ſuch a Lady.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: Such a bleſſing wet weather waſhes.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: At all, I will not go a lip leſſe my Lord.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Tis well caſt ſir.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: If Montague get more Wine, we are like to heare on't.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: I do not like that ſitting there.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Nor I, me thinks he looks like a Judge.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Now have I a kinde a grudging of a beating on me, I fear my hot ſit.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Drink apace, ther's nothing allays a cudgell like it.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: Montague, now I'le put my choyce to you; who do you hold in all this honor'd company a husband fit to enjoy thy Lady? ſpeak directly.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Shall I ſpeak Madam?

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: Montague, you ſhall.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Then as I have a ſoule i'le ſpeak my conſcience,
Give me more wine, in vino veritas,
Here's to my ſelf, and Montague have a care.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: Speak to th'cauſe.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Yes, Madam; firſt i'le begin to thee.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Have at us.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Now for a Pſalme of mercy.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: You good Mounſier, you that bely the noble Name of Courtier, and think your claime good here, hold up your hand; your VVorſhip is endited here, for a vaine glorious foole.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Good, oh ſir.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: For one whoſe wit
Lies in a ten pound waſtcoat, yet not warme;
Ye have travel'd like a Fidler to make faces,
And brought home nothing but a caſe of tooth-picks.
You would be married, and no leſſe then Ladies,
And of the beſt ſort can ſerve you; thou ſilke worm
What haſt thou in thee to deſerve this woman?
Name but the pooreſt piece of man, good manners,
Ther's nothing ſound about thee, faith thou'aſt none,
It lies pawn'd at thy ſilke mans, for ſo much lace;
Thy credit which is worſe cannot redeem it,
Thy cloaths are all the ſoule thou haſt, for ſo
Thou ſav'ſt them hanſome for the next great tilting
Let who wil take the t'other, thou wert never chriſten'd
Upon my conſcience (but in barbers water)
Thou art never out o'th baſen, thou art rotten,
And if thou darſt tell truth, thou wilt confeſſe it;
—thy skin
Looks of a Cheſtnut colour, greas'd with Amber
All women that on earth do dwell thou lov'ſt,
Yet none that underſtand love thee again,
But thoſe that love the Spittle, get thee home
Poor painted butter fly, thy ſummers pa'ſt;
Go ſweat and eat dry Mutton, thou mayſt live
To do ſo well yet; a bruis'd Chamber Maide
May fall upon thee, and advance thy follies.
You have your ſentence; now it followes Captaine,
I treat of you.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: Pray God I may deſerve it.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Beſhrow my heart he ſpeaks, plaine.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: That's plain dealing.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: You are a raſcall Captaine.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: A fine calling.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: A water coward.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: He would make a prety ſtuffe.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Nay I ſpeak freely Madam.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.l: Her's none ties you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Why ſhould'ſt thou dare come hither with a thought
To finde a wife here fit for thee? are all
Thy ſingle money whores that fed on Carrots,
And fild the high graſſe with familiars
Falne of to footmen? prethee tell me truly,
For now I know thou dar'ſt not lie, couldſt thou not
Wiſh thy ſelfe beaten well with all thy heart now,
And out of paine? ſay that I broke a rib,
Or cut thy noſe off, wert not mercifull for this ambition?

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Do your pleaſure ſir, beggars muſt not be chooſers.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: He longs for beating.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: But that I have nobler thoughts poſſeſſe my ſoule,
Then ſuch brown bisket, ſuch a peice of dog-fiſh,
Such a moſt mangy Mackrell eater as thou art
That dares do nothing that belongs toth'Sea,
But ſpue, and catch rats, and fear men of war,
Though thou haſt nothing in the world to looſe
Abord thee, but one piece of beefe, one Musket
Without a cock for peace ſake, and a pitch barrell,
I'le tell thee if my time were not more pretious
Then thus to looſe it, I would rattle thee,
It may be beat thee, and thy pure fellow,
The Merchant there of Catskins, till my words,
Or blowes, or both, made ye two branded wretches
To all the world hereafter; you would faine to
Venture your bils of lading for this Lady;
What would you give now for her? ſome five frayle
Of rotten Figs good, Godſon, would you not ſir?
Or a Parrat that ſpeaks high Dutch? can all thou ever ſaw'ſt
Of thine own fraughts from Sea, or coſonage
(At which thou art as expert as the devill)
Nay ſell thy ſoul for wealth to, as thou wilt do,
Forfeit thy friends, and raiſe a mint of Money,
Make thee dream all theſe double could procure
A kiſſe from this good Lady? can'ſt thou hope
She would lie with ſuch a nook of hell as thou art,
And hatch young Merchant-furies? oh ye dog-bolts
That fear no God but Dunkirks, I ſhall ſee you
Serve in a lowſy Lime boat, ere I die,
For mouldy cheeſe and butter Billingſgate
Would not endure, or bring in rotten Pippins
To cure blew eyes, and ſwear they came from China.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: Vex 'em no more, alas they ſhake:

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Down quickly on your marrow bones▪ and thank this Lady.
I would not leave you thus elſe, there are blankets,
And ſuch delights for ſuch knav s; but fear ſtill;
'Twill be revenge enough, to keep you waking.
Ye have no minde of Marriage, ha' ye?

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Surely no great mind now.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Nor you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Nor I, I take it.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Two eager ſutors.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Troth tis wonderous hot, God bleſſe us from him

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.l: You have told me Montague
Who are not fit to have me, let me know
The man you would point out for me.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: There he ſits; my Lord of Amiens, Madam, is my choyce, hee's noble every way, and worthy a wife with all the dowries of—

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Do you ſpeak ſir out of your friendſhip to me?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, and out of truth, for I could never flatter.

sp.speaker: Ami
sp.l: I would not ſay how much I owe you for it,
For that were but a promiſe, but Ile thank ye,
As now I find you, in deſpite of fortune,
A faire and noble Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.l: My Lords I muſt confeſſe the choyce this man hath made
Is every way a great one, if not too great,
And no way to be ſlighted: yet becauſe
We love to have our own eyes, ſometimes now
Give me a little liberty to ſee,
How I could fit my ſelfe, if I were put to't.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Madam we muſt.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: Are yee all agreed?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: We be?

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.l: Then as I am a maid, I ſhall chooſe here.
Montague, I muſt have thee.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Why Madam I have learnt to ſuffer more then you can (out of pitty) mock me with this way eſpecially.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.l: Thou think'ſt I jeſt now;
But by the love I bear thee, I will have thee.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: If you could be ſo weak, to love a falne man,
He muſt deſerve more then I ever can,
Or ever ſhall (deer Lady;) look but this way
Upon that Lord and you will tell me then
Your eyes are no true chooſers of good men.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Do you love him truely?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Yes my Lord, I will obey him truly, for I'le marry him, and juſtly thinke he that has ſo well ſerv'd mee with his obedience being borne to greatneſſe, muſt uſe mee nobly of neceſſity when I ſhall ſerve him.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: 'Twere a deepe ſin to croſſe ye, noble Montague,
I wiſh ye all content, and am as happy
In my friends good as it were meerly mine.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Your Lordſhip does ill to give up your right;
I am not capable of this great goodneſſe,
There ſits my wife that holds my troth.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I'le end all, I wooed you for my Lady, and now give up my title, alas poor wench, my aimes are lower far.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: How's this ſweet heart?

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.l: Sweet heart tis ſo, the drift was mine to hide
My purpoſe till it ſtruck home.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: God give you joy.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: Prethee leave wondring, by this kiſſe i'le have thee.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Then by this kiſſe, and this i'le ever ſerve ye.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: This Gentleman and I ſir muſt needs hop once more to follow yee.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: As friends and fellows, never as ſervants more.

sp.speaker: Long. Dub.
sp.p: You make us happy.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Friend Montague, ye have taught mee ſo much honor, I have found a fault in my ſelf, but thus I'le purge my conſcience of it, the late land I took by falſe play, from you with as much Contrition, and entireneſſe of affection to this moſt happy day again, I render; be Maſter of your own, forget my malice, and make mee worthy of your love, L. Montague.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: You have won me and honor to your name.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Since your Lordſhip has begun good deeds, wee'l follow; good ſir forgive us, we are now thoſe men fear you for goodnes ſake; thoſe ſums of money unjuſtly we detaine from you, on your pardon ſhall bee reſtord again, and we your ſervants.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: You are very forward ſir, it ſeems you have money, I pray you lay out, i'le pay you or pray for you, as the Sea works.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Their pennance ſir i'le undertake, ſo pleaſe ye
To grant me on concealement.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Right courtier, ſtill a begging.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: What is it ſir?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: A Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: In my gift?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Yes ſir, in yours.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Why bring her forth and take her.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.l: What wench would he have?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Any wench I think.

div.stage: Enter Laverdine and Veramour, like a Woman.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: This is the Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: 'Tis my Page ſir.

sp.speaker: Ʋer.
sp.l: No ſir, I am a poor diſguis'd Lady?
That like a Page have followed you full long for love god-wot.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: A Lady—Laverdine—yes, yes, tis a Lady.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: It may be ſo, and yet we have laine together,
But by my troth I never found her, Lady.

sp.speaker: L Orl.
sp.l: Why wore you boyes cloathes?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I'le tell you Madam,
I took example by 2 or 3. playes, that methought
Concernd me.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Why made you not me acquainted with it.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Indeed ſir I knew it not my ſelfe,
Untill this Gentleman opend my dull eyes,
And by perſwaſion made me ſee it.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Could his power in words make ſuch a change?

sp.speaker: Ʋer.
sp.l: Yes, as truly woman as your ſelfe my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Why but hark you, are not you a woman?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: If hands and face make it not evident, you ſhall ſee more.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Breeches, breeches, Laverdine.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: Tis not enough, women may wear thoſe caſes.
Search further Courtier.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: Oh thou freſhwater Gudgeon, wouldſt thou come
To point of Marriage with an Ignoramus?
Thou ſhouldſt have had her urin to the doctors,
The fooliſheſt Phiſitian could have made plaine
The liquid Epicaene; a blind man by the hand
Could have diſcoverd the ring from the ſtone.
Boy, come, to Sea with me, ile teach thee to climb,
And come down by the rope, nay to eate Rats.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I ſhall devour my Maſter before the priſon then,
Sir, I have began my Trade.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Trade? to the Citie, child, a flatcap will become thee.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Gentlemen I beſeech you moleſt your ſelves no further,
For his preferment it is determin'd.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I am much aſhamed, and if my cheek
Gives not ſatisfaction, break my head.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Your ſhame's enough ſir.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Montague, much joy attend thy marriage Bed;
By thy example of true goodneſſe, envie is exil'd,
And to all honeſt men that truth intend,
I wiſh good luck, faire fate be ſtill thy friend.

div.head: Vpon an Honeſt Mans Fortune.
div.l: YOu that can look through Heaven, and tell the Stars,
Obſerve their kind conjunctions, and their wars;
Find out new lights, and give them where you pleaſe,
To thoſe men honors, pleaſures, to thoſe eaſe;
You that are Gods ſurveyers, and can ſhow
How far, and when, and why the wind doth blow;
Know all the charges of the dreadfull thunder,
And when it will ſhoot over, or fall under:
Tell me, by all your art I conjure ye,
Yes, and by truth, what ſhall become of me?
Find out my ſtar, if each one, as you ſay,
Have his peculiar Angel, and his way;
Obſerve my fate, next fall into your dreames,
Sweep clean your houſes, and new line your ſceames,
Then ſay your worſt: or have I none at all?
Or is it burnt out lately? or did fall?
Or am I poor, not able, no full flame?
My ſtar, like me, unworthy of a name?
Is it, your art can only work on thoſe
That deale with dangers, dignities, and cloaths?
With love, or new opinions? you all lye,
A fiſhwife hath a fate, and ſo have I,
But far above your finding; he that gives,
Out of his providence, to all that lives,
And no man knowes his treaſure, no not you:
He that made Egypt blind, from whence you grew
Scaby and lowſy, that the world might ſee
Your calculations are as blind as ye,
He th●t made all the ſtars, you dayly read,
And from thence filtch a knowledge how to feed;
Hath hid this from you, your conjectures all
Are drunken things, not how, but when they fall;
Man is his own ſtar, and the ſoule that can
Render an honeſt, and a perfect man
Command all light, all influence, all fate,
Nothing to him fals early or too late.
Our acts our Angels arc, or good or ill,
Our fatall ſhadowes that walke by us ſtill,
And when the ſtars are labouring, we believe
Jt is not that they govern, but they grive
For ſtubborn ignorance; all things that are
Made for our generall uſes are at war,
Even we among our ſelves, and from the ſtrife
Your firſt unlike opinions got a life.
O man, thou image of thy makers good,
What canſt thou fear, when breath'd into thy blood
His ſpirit is, that built thee? what dull ſence
Makes thee ſuſpect, in need, that providence?
Who made the morning, and who plact the light
Guid to thy labours? who cal'd up the night,
And bid her fall upon thee, like ſweet ſhowers
In hollow murmurs, to lock up thy powers?
Who gave thee knowledge, who ſo truſted thee,
To let thee grow ſo neer himſelfe, the Tree?
Muſt he then be diſtruſted? ſhall his frame
Diſcourſe with him, why thus, and thus I am?
He made the Angels thine, thy fellowes all,
Nay even thy ſervants, when devotions call.
Oh canſt thou be ſo ſtupid then, ſo dim,
To ſeek a ſaving influence, and looſe him?
Can Stars protect thee? or can poverty,
Which is the light to Heaven, put out his eye?
He is my ſtar, in him all truth I find,
All influence, all fate, and when my mind
Is furniſhed with his fullneſſe, my poor ſtory
Shall outlive all their Age, and all their glory.
The hand of danger cannot fall amiſse,
When I know what, and in whoſe power it is.
Nor Want, the cauſe of man, ſhall make me groan,
A holy hermit is a mind alone.
Doth not experience teach us all we can
To work our ſelves into a glorious man?
Love's but an exhalation to beſt eyes
The matter ſpent, and then the fooles fire dyes?
Were I in love, and could that bright ſtar bring
Increaſe to wealth, honour, and every thing:
Were ſhe as perfect good as wee can aime,
The firſt was ſo, and yet ſhe loſt the Game.
My miſtris then be knowledge and faire truth;
So I enjoy all beauty and all youth,
And though to time her lights and lawes ſhe lends,
She knowes no Age that to corruption bends.
Friends promiſes may lead me to believe,
But he that is his own friend knowes to live.
Affliction when J know it is but this,
A deep allay whereby man tougher is
To bear the hammer, and the deeper ſtill,
We ſtill ariſe more image of his will.
Sickneſſe an humorous cloud twixt us and light,
And Death, at longeſt▪ but another night.
Man is his own Star, and that ſoule that can
Be honeſt is the only perfect man.
